reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you...

- like or liked building spaceships from Legos (and then smashing them)...
- are o. k. with playing a yet unfinished early access game in alpha-stage...
- have a decent rig...

...give Space Engineers a try!  (If you are patient/cautious, wait until it goes on sale.).

Space engineers is a block based building game, often described as minecraft in space, but with more realistic looks and physics. (Disclaimer: I have never played Minecraft because it is not in space.)

It has a creative mode, where you can comfortably just build spaceships (or bases, or vehicles) and a survival mode, where you need to mine and refine ore from asteroids or planets before you can expand beyond your starter-ship. In survival, you also need to generate energy and (unless you turn that option off) oxygen. Either way you get to build your own ship from hull to windows, doors, thrusters, gyros, antennas, refineries, cargo containers, fuel tanks, air vents, conveyors, batteries, missile launchers, landing gears (or wheels), cameras, sensors, timers, script blocks and more. Then you can fly your spaceship in an asteroid field, land on planets, set up bases, mine ores, fight pirates... Space Engineers is a sandbox game, so beyond not dying you have to set your own goals.

Of course you can save the ships you have built as blueprints and upload them to the workshop or download ships built by other players. There are some fantastic creations on the workshop. Actually, if you are interested in this game at all, I recommend you just take a quick look around the workshop to see what can currently be done in Space Engineers.

Space engineers is early access and still in alpha. The developers update the game every single thursday. That update will fix some things, add some things and, inevitably in this stage, break some things. Be sure to report bugs - that is what early access is for. The devs do a hotfix every friday, so that you can enjoy the game better over the weekend.

While the devs listen to the community - they added planets by popular demand - they have been too silent in the past. They are making an effort to improve, though.

Being alpha, the game is hardly optimzed yet, even though the devs work on that week by week, too. Older rigs may struggle with it. Performance in Singleplayer can be improved with the right settings and good judgement. Multiplayer however is currently being completely redone and perfomance varies from week to week.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit 12.2015: The game had some patches and some of my statements may no longer be true. I have not played the game for some time now and can not give feedback about the changes (planets, AI ships and more).



What do I do in the game?

(I have only played Survival but there is a creative mode, too)

- gather resources
- build a base
- build spaceships and other SiFi stuff
- fight NPC spaceships
- PvP

what I like:

- Science Fiction Setting
- Realistic Art-Style
- you can build spaceships that fly and shoot stuff!
- build your own tools (you can build spaceships with mining and/or crafting tools attached to them and use those ships to build even bigger ships or bases)
- working in-game programming language (code your own little programs to display container content on a display for example)(I believe it is C+ or something like that)

what I don't like:

- there is not enough to do besides building ships and stuff
- the NPC ships just fly a straight line and don't really engage in fights beside shooting their auto-aim turrets
- really, there is not much to do besides building and resource gathering

Summary:

I have mixed feelings about this game. The Building part is super fun. The Resource gathering is interesting because you build your own ships for the Job.
On the other hand, the lack of content besides building and gathering can make this game pretty boring pretty fast.
Interested in building cool spaceships or a moon base? This game might be something for you then.
But if you want to use the stuff you have build in cool combat scenarios, you need to join a public server or play with(against) friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I won't deny that I had a LOT of fun with this game, and my play time will speak on my behalf on that. But, as other early access titles, there's always a shadow looming over any potentially great title: the direction its developer will take, and how they will react to an unexpected success. I loved this game back when it was... simpler. Not in its mechanics, mind you, but in its SCOPE. It was a game in which you had to hone your space engineering skills (hence the name) to make better designs, and when you managed to build a well-designed, perfectly working ship... it was glorious. I remember how proud I was of the first semi-automated mining ship I built, the smile on my face brought me back 20 years, when I was a kid playing lego and building something I liked.

Then Keen Software House was hit by a wave of... success. They tried their best with their weekly update, and for some time I thought they were going in the right direction, with them adding programmable blocks and more engineering solutions to the already rich plate. Then they started trying to please everyone. Adding things most players didn't even want, failing to fix GAME BREAKING bugs, ignoring the pathetic state the multiplayer is in (completely unplayable as of now, has been like this for months).

Then the dreaded PLANETS. I won't lie, I was looking forward to them. But the engine showed the game itself wasn't ready for them, and they even changed the damn system requirements after adding that feature. Fact is, even with a mid to high-end gaming pc you won't be able to reach playable frame rates. I'm using a good machine myself, and my fps (10 to 20) on planet surfaces makes the game completely unplayable. And the bugs and unneeded features just keep coming.

We have exploding CYBERDOGS now, yey, and we can mod our medical room to suit our playing stile, imagine what kind of funny stuff we could do in multiplayer - oh wait... the multiplayer is currently broken. Keen is losing sight of their own creation, trying to subtly invite us to polish the game for them via MODS... their vision of this game's future is clouded by their own inadequacy.

I would NOT recommend this game to anyone right now, and I fear this might not change in the future, since the company behind it is quickly losing any credibility as a serious developer. If you're really interested in this title... well, my suggestion would be to wait. Wait and see if they can (and want to) come up with solutions to this game's long standing bugs (mining not working properly, terrible sim speed, unacceptable optimization, unplayable multiplayer) and make the right steps in order to keep the title alive. If so, I'd gladly change my review at a later date. But right now... avoid this game. It will make you think this could have been GREAT
date: when and how did it go so wrong?"."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a great game. What is it? Imagine Minecraft having kids with space with difficulty surpassing all other games you have ever played and great modding potential. Maybe I'm overexaggerating because the game isn't that hard when you disable some stuff but trying to capture a cargo ship with automated turrets with your little fighter is hard and the space doesn't forgive. If you get shot and die it's not minecraft your stuff is gone for good and you'll not find it unless it's stationary or marked, or going really slow for some reason. You have to menage your resources well and pick your fights if you plan on fighting. There are also pirates that sometimes spawn and you have to attack their base or they'll keep sending drones and some alien NPCs like big spiders and cyberhounds. The game is updated every week and it's amazing that developers DO care. You can create a lot of different stuff in Space Engineers and you can even code in game. Space Engineers is all about usability of your creations but it doesn't stop you from building 1:1 Death Star with empty interior, it's just not as fun in my eyes as making something more... technical.

Controls might be confusing at first but you can remap 95% of stuff and it's great. The game has a lot of tutorials but I've never played them since I bought the game years prior to tutorials and simply watched update videos to learn the game.
You can play either Survival, Creative or some workshop scenarios. All modes are great. I love spawning planets in Creative with different seeds, they're so sexy, mrrr. Survival is really, really great and it has been greatly improved since I first bought into the game and made more accessible and faster for single player. Multiplayer is loads of fun and I recommend you bring friends if you plan on playing Survival because it's the best thing to do in the game. Graphics vary but there are some really cool solutions in here and it's not Minecraft level of graphics, this isn't square world - only the blocks are square 100%, destruction of ships is really great and blocks do not destroy instantly like said MC - destruction looks very real and ramming mothership with other mothership into a side is fu**ing omhack fapfapfap.

I really enjoy the soundtrack. Both battle music and the slower pace tunes are good.
The game truly has a lot to offer and you can build a lot of different vehicles or even make a small ship into a guided rocket or a turret. The game is still a little bit buggy but recent updates are all about bugfixes and optimization.
On the topic of optimization it's not really that great but it's hard to tell why. It's just not always good but even in world with 25 planets I'm k but when I eg. land on a planet or spawn a really big fu**ing ship then it might not be as good. And I have a very good PC soo yea it's sad. The game is loads of fun alone or with friends, creative or survival, map making or building sh*t, fighting with motherships or raiding an NPC vessel with fighters. I recommend you support the devs, the game is really worth it even though it's not perfect. Remember, you can only play planets if your video card supports DX11. Otherwise the game is playable in DX9.

The Dark Souls sandbox in space with great modding support I've always wanted
96/100.

+ for:
Customizability
Lots of options to create advanced mechanisms
Multiplayer, SP, Creative, Sandbox, Scenario mode (community made maps/vanilla maps/map making)
Soundtrack
Planets are stunning to look at
The game is fair but hard if you want it to be
Great modding support
Weekly updates that do indeed add stuff and fix stuff (progress of the game)
Physics (destruction and all the other stuff that makes the game more difficult to build vehicles capable of flying above planet's surface etc. it's all so cooool)
You can make everything out of this game
Very tactical with where you set up your base to defend it more easily and to avoid meteor storms, battling cargo ships, managing resources and trying to stay alive and with oxygen etc. (unless you turn these features off)

- for:
Optimization (big -)
Some major Scenario features I'd love to see there are still missing
Multiplayer code isn't as great as it could've been
They deleted ladders years ago and they're out of the game since then... guys give up with your gravity elevators and stairs we just want fricking ladders.
Crashes (sometimes)
No water on planets (only ice)
This isn't a great FPS regardless of having Assault Rifles (lackluster shooting with your astronaut/space engineer altough still being worked on and it keeps getting better)

The money you invest now is the money you'll get back in fun time pretty quickly and even more money over time since with each update game becomes more expensive and it's getting better and better so it's definetely worth to buy it because it's 99/100 material and 100/100 if they CAN and WILL MANAGE to make the optimization great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Review based on game as of March 2016*
This is a very conflicting game for me to review. On one hand there are things about this game that are amazing, which I get excited about, on the other hand I find there are just so many problems and bugs which are holding the game back.

I'll start with the negatives. This game is very poorly optimised. I know this game has a lot to render, but the framerate on planets is less than satisfactory even with a reasonably strong PC running on low settings. Planets offer the most interesting gameplay currently, so it's a shame to have to deal with this issue. (I do understand this is an early access game, and optimisation usually comes later in the development cycle, I'm merely commenting on the current state of the game). I usually play on a private server with a small group of friends. During our time playing we have encountered a variety of bugs and frustrations. One of the worst was after a few days building a station on a planet, it decided to flip, damaging or destroying much of our work. This was immensely frustrating, especially as we were also dealing with occasional crashes to both client and server. We also had issues with turrets targeting dogs and just shooting our station instead, causing damage. Not to mention the dogs themselves, which seem to spawn randomly and appear with not much warning. They seem very simple and could do with work. I also find the UI to be a but clunky, but that may be more down to personal preference.

That aside, this game has a lot of very nice features. The planets are huge and impressive to see, even though they haven't been in the game too long. The physics in the game is good and the technical side to building ships and stations has plenty of depth, whilst still leaving room for creativity. The resource gathering system is cool too, starting with basic hand drills, up to large mining ships, there is really no limit to how far you can go with this game, as long as you have the time.

In summary, this game has plenty of impressive core features but is plagued by frustrating bugs, features and poor optimisation which are currently holding it back. I am highly confident this game will be an amazing experience at some point in the future, but a little patience may be required.

Pros:
-Planets
-Good physics
-Good ship/station building mechanics
-Mining

Cons:
-Bugs, some severe
-Crashes
-Dogs are a bit simple
-Poor optimisation

Final verdict:
4.9/10
Maybe pick it up on sale to give it a test, otherwise stay patient maybe until it comes out of early access.

~edited to fix a few spelling errors

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a sandbox game about construction, engineering, and maintenance of objects in space. This includes small ships, large ships, space stations, and platforms. It features a simple crafting system, jetpacks, survival and creative modes, as well as multiplayer! Space Engineers is developed by Keen Software House,  the same team behind Miner Wars.

The game revolves around the player collecting resources from the asteroids and rocks floating out in space. To reach them you can utilize either a ship you've built (or started with) or your trusty jetpack. Once you've reached a location, you can then scout out materials and begin mining them. Once you have sufficient resources, you can then craft things such as a cockpit, thrusters, a gyroscope, a gravity generator, and reactors...all of which are required for building a ship. Multiplayer can be quite challenging, as it will have you coordinating with other players to build large stations and ships for moving and storing items as you establish a base of operations and then go out and find new sources of ore and materials.

Everything in this game is destructible. And I mean EVERYTHING. What you've built, what your friend has built....even your friend! If your ship is about to crash into a station, you can do your best to evade but you will most likely fail, and destroy half of the station AND the ship. And the thing is that the developers actually put the effort into that! The destructed objects look very realistic and look like they had some thought put into hnow they would look if destroyed a certain way (Rammed by a ship for example)! Fly a ship into another ship and check it out. Broken objects, pieces of metal, and more will all be floating away through space after a stellar impact.

Space Engineers is currently still in Alpha, and is available on Steam via the Early Access program. While it is still very early in its life, Space Engineers is very playable, and a blast to play with a few friends. Get a few together, grab a four-pack of the game, and you will definitely get share of fun from this game.

Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

91% of nearly 42,000 people have given this game a positive rating. How do you go against that?

Well, here's how I do it.

Space Engineers is a fantastic game if you're prepared to play a local, single player game. It works quite well, with only a reasonably small amount of bugs for an Alpha game.

Space Engineers is a terrible game if you'd like to play a dedicated server, multiplayer game. It barely works, with a large array of game breaking bugs for an Alpha game. Furthermore, some deliberate design decisions by Keen will ensure that sooner or later, entire ships, cargo and inventory are lost, and done so on a regular basis.

Overall, I'd really like to like this game - and if playing forever by myself was an option, I reckon I'd love it. However, until the cheap and fatally flawed multiplayer code can be fixed (or completely dumped and replaced with something that works) and until some key design decisions can be reversed that stop penalising players for the frequent disconnections induced by said multiplayer code, this is a game whose multiplayer capabilities are best expressed in abstract terms only.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A creative and exciting game where you get the incredible opportunity to be a space miner and build your own ship. You spend the first hour of the game going around space and getting excited about how cool your life is, and getting basic resources, like iron and uranium. You spend the second hour building your own amazing ship, which is all fine until you realise that you have got no silicon so you can't build squat. Hour 2 to 12 is spent flying around space in a desperate attempt to find Silicon, while your co-op friends shout at you for being worhtless and politely suggest that you should end your own life. You, of course, find no silicon.
Hour 12 to 20 is spent alone, crying on the cold hard floor of your bathroom, mumbling incoherently about Silicon - this is where the game breaks the 4th barrier and enters your real life, forcing you to re-evaluate your priorities.
10/10, best no-Silicon simulator in the whole Universe.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine if you had limitless sets of space themed Lego and you are getting close to the basic premise of Space Engineers. Build, Experiment and Conquer!

Combining parts of Minecraft, Kerbal and traditional space games, you are given a sandbox of possibilities to explore solo or with friends (or foes). From role-playing servers, PVP and creative modes, there's plenty to keep occupied.

The only caveat is that there is no enemy AI or NPCs, so if you are looking for something like Wing Commander, or similiar, you might be out of luck until they decide to implement AI into the game.

With constant updates, great mechanics and very stable gameplay, Space Engineers is one of the few Early Access titles I can recommend.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is an Early Access space sandbox game, developed by Keen Software House (you might also know them from Medieval Engineers or Miner Wars games). Although it's not yet fully released, it already features a great deal of content.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

Note: I played this game when I was on vacation with no internet so playtime and achievements were not registered for some reason. It was a nice vacation, though.
What is happening in the game:People would tell you that it's basically Minecraft in space and they wouldn't be wrong. You can build ships and bases, fly around and mine. What to do in the game is basically your choice, as in all sandbox games.

Pros:    There are both survival and creative mode. As you can assume, creative mode is for creating, without any real danger you would need to deal with. Survival mode, on the other hand, need a bit more skill when playing, as you have to be careful not to die or lose the energy, there are meteor showers ...
Of of the best things in the game is Workshop integration. With 120k+ user-created items submitted, it is obvious that the game is fun enough for that many gamers to post their own creations. There is everything: ships, characters, asteroids ... you name it.
A pretty good tutorial introduces you nicely to many features in the game, even the basic movement ones, if you've never played any games before.
Some reviews say that this game is abandoned by the developer, however, there are regular updates coming out about twice a month.
Even though I'm pretty sure it's not very realistic, it still gives the impression of being like that. Space battles and stuff like that is of course not transferred from the real life, but other content might very well be.
A part I'm very thrilled about is in-game programming. You use C# language to write scripts.
For a game in Early Access there is a ton of content and things to do. Reminded me of Prison Architect. Impressive.
Cons:    The price is pretty high for an Early Access game. You should at least put the price a bit lower for the testers! It is true, however, that this game has been bundled twice already (at the time of writing this review).
Building stuff takes a long time, ruining it takes seconds. There is Workshop for the lazy people, though.
Despite having relatively low system requirements, this game runs slower than it should. I believe they're going to fix that before they get out of Early Access.
No Linux and MacOS support. I am not familiar with what engine they're using for this game, but most modern ones support other platforms than Windows.
The final verdict:If you are one of the people who love sandbox games (not everybody do), you should consider getting this game. Even though it's in EA, it has tons of content, Workshop support for a few more tons of content and more features will be coming with future updates. The game is fun, not that buggy and it includes both creative and survival mode.
I've played Space Engineers a lot already, some people even spent hundreds of hours on it, in case you're worried about how many hours this games can offer.
For people who like sandboxes, this is certainly a recommended game.

Further reading:    Store page
Features[www.spaceengineersgame.com]
Space Engineers Wiki[www.spaceengineerswiki.com]
Gameplay on Youtube
Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is an Early Access game and have been for quite a while. It is in Early Access game with quite a bit of content and more is being added on constantly.

What is in the game?
This is an open sandbox game with lots to explore, it is not your typical sandbox game, it is a unique sandbox-space game. There is lots to do, you can build spaceships, explore outerspace, build space stations, have ship fights with friends in your almost fully destrutible enviroment.


Is this game worth the money? Personally I think it is worth it, there is so much to do in this game, there is two game modes, Survival and Creative. Pretty self explanatory but Survival is where you are trying to gather your supplies and trying to survive and create your spacestation, but in creative you get to create your own spaceship or spacestation or whatever you want to make with all the tools at your fingertips.
Yes the game is a bit expensive 25$ at the moment, it did go up recently from 20$ if you dont want to spend that much then just wait for a sale when it will be much cheaper.
The game is fun but even more fun with some friends to mess around with.

Pros Huge Workshop, there are over 150 thousand workshop submissions from Spacestations, Spaceships, and all kinds of machines.
Regular updates to the games, some great devolopers working on this game they update 1-2 times a month.
Great game there is so much to do, you can have huge space battles with friends, build an army of spaceships, have races in fast spaceships, build a deathstar.
There is a great high detailed tutorial that helps you figure out this game which can be pretty complicated at first.

Cons
Again this game is a bit expensive, 25$ is quite expensive for some people but it does go on sale and when it does you should get yourself a copy and maybe one for a friend.
The controls for flying ships are a bit hard but once you get used to them it becomes more enjoyable.
It does take a while to build stuff and can be challenging and frustrating when a friend or someone or even yourself destroys your creation in a matter of seconds

My final thoughts and opinion of Space EngineersThis game is still in Early Access and is one of the better sandbox games i have seen and played so far. There is 100s of hours of gameplay to offer and maybe even thousands. There is plenty of mods to try out and play. There isnt very many gamebreaking bugs (or none that i have found or heard of) but the developers are always updating and patching bugs. This is a great game for early access and i am excited to see what is to come later, i highly recommend this game to fans of sandbox games, and fans of building games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers, my Part time 'job' for the last two years. It was the foundations from which I wanted to become a game developer and 3D artist. And I have seen it grow since it's inception.
There are very good reasons why this game is as highly rated and prized for it's gameplay and development, and also as much reasons why it is still following the early access model.
As I am writing this, it has been a few months since I had a long session of building and interacting with the community. The long hours I made in this game and the great people I met on the workshop and forums are the reasons I am still coming back. This game is a timesink, but the reasons why you play differ per player. I am of the creative sorts and love sharing my creations on the workshop. Others may jump into a survival server and love the interaction and building together with friends or anyone at all.
The game has a solid foundation, with a lot of potential, yet a lack of polish. That is now written of as 'early access' yet it also seems that the focus of SE lies on the core mechanics, and allowing their players and dedicated modders to expand on the assets, code and additional features one would find in competitor games.

I myself have never indulged myself in the survival and multiplayer scene in the way SE presents it to their players. I prefer working in self made scenarios and creating the sandbox environment as a filming studio. Making machinimas or just a show and tell.

I have had a blast with this game, yet sometimes you need a break to rewind your creative gears. I have had a break of a few months before, and when my time is plenty again, I will definitely get back building!

Pros
Unique physics and deformation engine
Continues updates and community feedback
Unlimited value if you are into sandbox games and space. (2000 hrs and counting)
Multiplayer
Modding support.
Many other things.

Cons
Terrible User interface
Lack of Polish in models, characters, variety and depth of existing game elements
A lot of work arounds and limitations in gameplay. In the form of artificial maximum speeds and stopping physics calculations at certain speeds.
Multiplayer is not reliable (Netcode is not done on the moment of writing this)
Many other things aswell halas.

Final Verdict
It is a platfrom perfect to continue your creativity and physics nonsense you expect from other sandbox games. I love this game to death, the team behind it is great and the community is one of the friendliest I ever encountered.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of my overall favorite games of all time.

The crafting and survival systems are all very well balanced, fun, and gives you a great sense of accomplishment as you build yourself up from a basic ship/base trying to meet your basic energy needs all the way up to a multi-planet power.

The engineering and design elements are both challenging and engaging. It tests my creativity to come up with functional and aesthetic design, but the end result is more than worth it.

The game definitely has more than it's fair share of bugs, however. Optimization is poor at best, and there are multiple game crashing bugs that I run into regularly.

That having been said, the developers have put in a staggering number of new features since the game was released, including the MASSIVE and game changing Planets update that was never even initially planned. And the last month or so, they have focused exclusively on bug fixing and it's really starting to show.

Overall, the game has issues that I would consider unplayable in MOST games. However, the fun of the game outweighs the frustration by miles, and with the developers history of listening to the fans, I have absolutely full confidence the devs will work out the kinks.

I would call this game a must have.

No regrets in buying this. It's one of my favorites."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is so enveloping! The first time I tried survival, I died several times while trying to build a ship because I forgot to build a place to recharge my suit. Then, after about a few hours of building a small mining ship I finished; Only to crash it while mining an asteroid far from base. the only bad side about this game is the buggy multiplayer, but the devs have promised to fix that once planets are out!

The Skybox has been changed and looks spectacular! Also, there's now a speaker block, so you can easily rig a simple alarm to tell you if you're going to run into a wall, someone entered your ship, etc.

With the addition of exploration mode, your world can be almost infinite! Now the game features an alpha prototype of Scenarios, which will be basically like single player missions.

Planets are now here, and i must say, they look fantastic! Unfortunately, I personally had some problems with getting high FPS, but after tweaking the graphics settings a little, it was fixed.

Tip: Don't turn grass multiplier up to 10 and then set to HIGH definition of foliage. Great way to break your computer.

9/10 A great game that continues to get better!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the best sandbox games I have ever played, too many good things to say about it...but I have to give it a thumbs down...

I really want to give this a thumbs up but I can't.

The most important POSITIVE aspects of the game:
-Active developers (it's been a few years and the developers haven't quit on us, and if anything they are now spending every mintue of their personal life trying to better the game and not give up on the community, an update every Thursday)
-Survival and creative are both amazing gameplay features
-Multiplayer multiplies the fun factor of this game
-No limit in replayability (build and survive however, and whatever you want)
-The visuals are stunning for an alpha game (especially planets)
-Gameplay is very easy but complex, there is a learning curve but it's worth it in the end

The most important NEGATIVE aspects:
-Optimizations (when it comes to having to use DX11, performance is not too stable, planets can drop your framerate to 5FPS
-Bugs. There are so many bugs that can break the game, like flying through a solid asteroid, mining into a planet, or just multiplayer bugs in general

So you're wondering why I don't recommend it. Well frankly there are WAY too many bugs (especially in multiplayer) and the optimizations are horrendous.

I know it's alpha and we expect those to be present but it got to the point where it is so bad that a lot of people don't play this. What really killed it is the release of planets. Yes, I love the planets, great idea and great execution but there are just too many bugs and terrible framertaes that keep me away from playing it.

Once the devs stop adding and start fixing, then I will come back. Just keep checking, every few weeks, up on the game and see if the game has improved. P.S. It's been five months, since the release of planets, and the optimizations are still poor and there are so many bugs that keep me away from playing this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

short review: great concept, lots of potential, fun to play, large variety and easy use of mods.
Sadly the game is weakened by lots of bugs even by Early access standards, multiplayer hardly playable, weekly updates causing more problems than they solve. I recommend buying it at a discounted price or in a few months when hopefully the most annoying bugs will be resolved.

PROS:
-you can build nearly everything you can imagine

-large world maps including huge planets ready to be explored.

-provides interesting engineering challenges for building spaceships/stations, planetary bases etc.

-Survival and creative mode Wich allows you to play the way you want

-Huge amount of player scenarios and creations to play with, and you can publish your own easily!

- large variety of mods available on the workshop, to enhance your experience

-multiplayer mode


CONS
-weekly updates create more problems than they solve, forcing you to face new bugs every week

-they main engineering features, rotors and pistons, still cause problems since their implementation

-the amount of issues is too much, even by Early access standards

-poor optimization, compatibility issues with graphic cards

-the game can't handle huge structures or big scenarios

-lack of proper enemies in survival mode

-multiplayer users experience most of the bugs, to the point of being unplayable

-tutorials are insufficient to explain game mechanics

CONCLUSION
It's an amazing concept, and I have no doubts that more stable updates will remove most of the issues. It's worth buying at a later date, however, when major bugs in MP and SP will be resolved. The constant instability of the game due to new bugs introduced every week is going to turn you off from playing it. That's why this review is negative. Space Engineers needs to have more stable updates, and bugs must be at least not evident the moment we start the game. Early access can exscuse most of them, but some don't need even testing to be seen, and those are not exscusable.

I am confident that in the upcoming months major bugs will eventually be resolved, and thus I recommend SE at a later date or at discounted price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers: A Game of Infinite Possibility
The History

I initially purchased Space Engineers during it's Early Access period fairly close to its arrival on Steam on recommendation by a good friend. Until recently, Space Engineers was a game I would play heavily for a month or so, and then put down for an indefinite amount of time until I got the itch to build a sci-fi wet dream all over again. About two months ago, I heard that there was some talk about putting planets into the game, and I decided to ease myself back into the mechanics before the launch of the new update, which proved to be counter-intuitive as the update changed everything I knew about the game.

The Review

As the mechanics of the game itself have heavily changed since the introduction of planets, this section will cover my thoughts post-update. Planetary gravity has revolutionized everything about the way this game is played from the ground up. When I first loaded up my new world, I found myself amidst the derelict husk of a spaceship in the middle of the night somewhere on the face on an earthlike planet, out of broadcasting range of my friends. We initially spent the first two hours discovering we were out of range of the strongest beacons, and that we couldn’t seem to build a ship strong enough to escape the planets gravity, much less keep them upright during the building process. Eventually we discovered that it all came down to mass, center of gravity, and the angle at which we tried to escape the atmosphere.

This is what draws me to launching this game every night, the sudden tangibility of the  world  solar system post-update. You can easily lose a ship you spent hours assembling due to a misplaced thruster, crashing into a planet leaving nothing but a crater behind. The map spaces are so large that you can lose your base, your friends, and all sense of direction. The core difference between gameplay as it exist now compared to a year ago, is that you frequently have to build something to address a crisis, and not just because you want to.

Despite all of the positives this game brings to the table, it does struggle with some graphical and physics based glitches. While most of these boil down to minor annoyances in the grand scheme of the game, there have been moments when these issues have rendered my game unplayable.

It would be a travesty to discuss what makes this game great without touching on the fantastic modding community attached to it. The people who love this game have created everything from small physics fixes to gigantic rail canons capable of punching a whole through practically anything. You would be missing out if you didn't browse through the Steamworkshop for this title.

The Takeaway

This game provides a form of sci-fi fantasy fulfillment rooted in compelling physics, and a fantastic community. While this is not a game for the easily frustrated, as it suffers from a variety of technical and graphical glitches, I have found that almost any question I have is answered shortly by a quick browse through the forums, and the developer has frequently implemented changes derived from player feedback (i.e. the planets update). If you are willing to invest the time to learn the games physics and nuanced mechanics, the payoff is worth it.

Good fit for: Sci-fi fans, Simulator junkies, Creative types. Bad fit for: Fast-paced gamers, Glitch haters.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is of the Early Access (pre-release) version of the game, current as of 10/13/2014, and pertains almost exclusively to the Survival mode of the game.

Early access it may be, but Space Engineers is worth a look if you enjoy builders (eg. Minecraft-style) games. I've spent much of the past weekend mining, refining, assembling, and then building the components of various ships and devices, to much enjoyment. Flight is Newtonian, jetpacks are standard, and the freedom of flight on top of the construction mechanics is enjoyable.

However, like most builder games, Space Engineers has a large element of resource collection and extraction. In this case, it's also part of the charm - there's nothing like building your first tunnel-boring machine and using it to core right through an enormous asteroid - but expect to spend some time mining if you're not simply playing creative mode. That means some relatively mundane mining - whether it's small scale mining by hand, or large scale resource extraction. It also means finding ores, but the game provides tools for this (ore detectors, lights, and conveyor/connector systems) to permit a player to facilitate this as much as possible mechanically without actually removing it.

When creating a survival mode world, give some consideration to your intended style of play. For instance, the game offers the opportunity to let welding (construction), grinding (deconstruction), refining (ores into ingots), assembly (ingots into components), and general inventory size be faster, more efficient, or simply larger. These changes can alter a survival mode game into something much more like the creative mode, or allow a single player to have the ability to move the ores and components of ten men when multiplayer is not available. None of this will stop a single player from playing as they wish, but it will have an impact on the level of tedium a player may have to ignore or overcome to enjoy the game.

Full disclosure: I'm currently playing a all settings realistic" Lone Survivor start

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was pretty skeptical about buying into yet another early access game when looking into Space Engineers and it took some more convincing than the usual reading through the Steam store but eventually I did end up getting the game. To my delight the development team has been really hard at work with releasing updates which more often than not contain noticeably good tweaks to content and optimization. Updates are seen at a regular interval of about twice a month and if there's one thing I learned from fooling myself into getting Starforge and watching the progress of Starbound it's that steady updates are king and there's nothing more irritating that developers who spend more time talking about how great the game will be when it's finished than they do working on the game. As with any early access game there's still a lot of work to be done; the most recent update was as a fantastic jump on optimization which allows for collisions to be made without losing literally all of your frames for a few seconds but the Survival mode which was also implemented with it is still at a lackluster state where it's only really worth checking out if you want to demo what will soon come around. You can't really lose with holding out on buying an early access game but if you're considering Space Engineers I feel that I can tell you it's worth picking up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well let me start out saying I have  1,611.3 hrs on record for this game so far. This game had tons of potential only to fall short due to bugs that never get fixed or never stay fixed (pistons for one).

They seem more interested in adding more features vs fixing all the deep issues this game has. It's nearly impossible to have a stable server with a player count over 8 to 10 people if they are all active mining/whatever.

In my opinion they should get the game as stable as they can then add features after that, but logging in and having bookmarks/ships/whatever up and disappear for no good reason makes it hard to play multiplayer.

To even think about hosting a half way stable server you have to run third party tools like server extender even then you have to jump through a lot of hoops. I couldn't tell you why keen didn't hired the person who made Server Extender, the server end would be a bit better if they did.

I usually get a itch for the game every so often and will play for a bit until I cant deal with the bugs anymore and quit for a while hoping they fix it at some point only to keep being repeatedly disappointed.

If you catch it under $10 on sale and want to gambling it will turn into something better go for it. With keens past history I hope they just dont release the xbox version and bail out on us. We shall see.

With all the negative comments I have posted above I will say when the game works with out crashing or pistions killing you and your entire family its unlike any other game thats out.

My expectations of a great space engineers game would be to have at least 30 people doing whatever they want with in reason and no lag/slow down on the server.

But go look for yourself if you have it pull up a server list see how many servers have 15 or more people in them, not many.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a very detailed, very impressive sandbox crafting game set in space.  It consists of building things, exploration and gathering resources for said building.

The highlights of the game are that you can make pretty much whatever you want, and that you can be as specific in your building as your patience allows right down to each block.

The physics are also noteworthy and make it stand out from similar games, particularly in regards to destruction and how things visually break depending on the point and force of impact.

Very few bugs are present especially for an Early Access game, most of which can be fixed with a simple relog.

Space Engineers is lots of fun and well worth your time, either alone or with your friends.

If you'd like to see some not-so-serious antics between friends in this game, feel free to check out the video below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JKPb1U2-2eU

And the complete playlist here:

http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLklrkLw7j3VSOI6R8GfkrR85Mg_WE8bfJ

I hope this review helped you!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is almost infinitely detailed within well-defined limits: you're a space engineer, and you can create various moving and non-moving structures in space: space ships, space stations, robots, hovercrafts, wheeled vehicles, and the like. There's a survival mode to make this more interesting, as well: you'll need to collect ore from various asteroids for raw materials for your creations. Because of the amount of complexity, you can also create your own 'game modes', if you put your mind to do it - moreso than unmodded Minecraft. The physics are 'real' - you'll have to worry about gravity, structural integrity, damage, and momentum. Flying your first ship is a thrilling experience; being crushed or slingshotted by a stray piece of dismantled ship or space trash is, as well. It seems to really shine in multiplayer but none of my friends have bought it yet - hopefully this review can play a part in changing that! Also, the game is updated with new mechanics and features much faster than I can keep up - it's freakily exciting to see each dev update and see that they've added two or three amazingly complex but well-thought-out additions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game isn't perfect, and it doesn't have kerbal space program physics, but it is still really fun, especially on multiplayer.

The developers are awesome. They care what the community wants, and they are keeping it a really good game. Originally, the developers were not going to add planets, but so many people requested it, and guess what? They added them!

The community is awesome as well, however, like any community there is the bad part of it. Try creating a public creative server, it won't work too well, it'll just have spammers. At least until mod api supports more. Aside from the creative servers, you can find a community you love being around, just takes time to find one.

Missing content to the game? Look to the modding community, there is tons and tons of content created for the game.

Pros:
- Infinite worlds, just explore or create a huge empire.
- PLANETS!!! They are beautiful in every way, they're just gigantic, I mean like... MASSIVE. Oh, and... The best part, The ENTIRE planet can be destroyed, sure that takes up a lot of resources, but its possible. You could make a hole from 1 side to another.
- Building mechanics are awesome, many decoration mods to make ships feel like they're actually a space ship.
- Enjoyable if you play with your friends, teamwork can make things a lot faster.
- The game sort of has a goal now, starting on a planet, and moving up into space, and jump drives being end game. The alien planet is far away, and is dangerous and very exciting to be on, and be eaten alive!
- Planets do not support DX9, why is this a Pro? Because DX9 is like extremely old and outdated.

Cons:
- The game is getting better at optimization, still laggy, but getting better. Consider the scale of the game, and what it has now.
- Some patches released can break the game a bit, but generally they're getting better, after all, it still is Alpha.
- The game pushes limits, so don't expect it to run on your 2005 dell computer, it's not going to. The game requires nice hardware, but at the same time, the game is pushing the limits by adding  content that has never been done before.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Keeping this short. Space Engineers has a lot of promise. First however, it needs a lot of fixing. Server side I am aware of a nominally fixed memory leak caused by voxel updates (we think, hard to be sure). Not ACTUALLY fixed, despite patch notes: our server admin has tested this thoroughly.

Client side... I don't know where to begin. Sometimes my oxygen won't replenish, or my energy, when sitting in a pod with both supplied. Sometimes objects literally destroy themselves while I build them. Just now I lost almost two hours of solid work because things I build don't always default to BELONGING TO ME.

My advice is pretty simple. Wait until the devs iron out most of these things before giving them money for the project. Currently it is frustratingly prone to glitchy behavior, and while the game is playable you will see tons of things go wrong.

Tl;dr, Dark Souls 3 is more rewarding and less frustrating than this. Infer what you will from that.

For this game being in early access I find it very time consuming and fun, though you will crash, A LOT if you're the host of a server. I would rate this game overall an 7/10 due to its many crashes and lag spikes, once this has a few patches I'm going to edit this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a very promising, inspiring and creative game. If you like playing alone in an empty universe, then you must definitely try this game. You won't regret it. It is one of the best single-player sandbox games I have ever played.

Everything is great until you try the multiplayer.
Extremely unstable, insanely laggy, frustratingly buggy.

No, it's not my internet connection (I have a very fast connection) and no, it's not my pc (I have a very high end pc).
It's just that the game is severely unoptimized. Whenever I join an online server, the game switches to s**t mode.

There are so many things not working in multiplayer that I can't possibly list them here, some of which are:

- Lag gets so extreme that you must wait for 30 seconds for even the most simple action
- Game freezes for 10 - 20 seconds for no apparent reason
- Player jumping all over the place, without any chance of controlling it
- Lag stuttering gets so intense that can give you a seizure
- On planets, player suddenly starts sinking into the ground, free falling to the center of the planet and ultimately dying
- Sudden death for completely inexplicable reasons
- Parked vehicles explode for no reason
- Stationed ships explode for no reason
- Drills and rotors explode for no reason
- Merge blocks explode for no reason
- Parked vehicles jumping all over the place for no reason
- Stationed ships jumping all over the place for no reason

You get the idea.

Overall, great for single-player, unplayable in multiplayer.
Yes, it is in early access but there are serious bugs that remain unsolved for 2 years and I don't think they will be ever solved.

Looks like this game suffers from the eternal-early-access syndrome, which is very common these days.

reviewText:

This game is like a relationship you love and hate at the same time. You know, a person who looks great and you can have a lot of fun with, but ruins every moment with annoying nagging and sudden emotional explosions. This person knows how stressful this is for you and promises to change this attitude, but simply won't do that. To hide that, this person makes you presents in order to make you forget those flaws. But you don't want those presents... You want this relationship to work!

That's pretty much this game.

Heck darn, it's fun to play.. or it WOULD be fun to play! Establishing a base, building ships and do things with other players? Sounds awesome! But all thouse freakouts in multiplayer makes it almost unenjoyable. Recently I found a server and played hours on it because the performance was bearable... Yeah, you can call hourly server crashes, violent twitching of objects and other bunches of bugs 'bearable'. Singleplayer or private MP runs almost flawless, but that's not the space adventure you want to have. You want to communicate with other people! Trade with them, explore with them, fight with them!
Trust me, I'd LOVE to give this a positive review, but I can't. Not with all those problems. The developers made me have hope for this game, but that hope vanishes with every session i play. As long as it stays like this, my thumb stays down.

Restrictions & LimitationsOriginally posted by Silver:In sandbox games you want to build, be creative and be free.
But the freedom is limited by the server performance which is killed really easy w/o rules that limit your freedom.Yes servers MUST apply serious restrictions to all players (like deleting all ships with more than x blocks). And yet you can still crash any server you want without hacking/cheating. Another example: there is a hidden block limit for each ship, exceeding it will cause a crash. Official reply from Keen stated (literal copy-paste): We will try to take a look at it. But it will not probably be fixed.".

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I miss the times where servers weren't speed capped at 50 m/s.

The times where you could actually move around normally without your character taking off into the sky when you move your mouse around with high sensitivity..

Something went wrong, really, really wrong. I don't know how or what it has been caused by but damn, do I miss the old game.. It makes me cry deep inside of me whenever I try to play on a server, it's like trying to get into something again but then it just scrubs you in the face with a metal brush.

And the times where multiplayer.. ughh nevermind, I bet most of you guys weren't playing the game from the start, so you don't know how I feel like about Space Engineers right now, the optimizations destroy the game rather than make it better, I remember a few patches back multiplayer was actually stable, but now it's A LOT worse.

New ships sounds don't really fit in, and they're skimmed off Elite: Dangerous, doesn't really feel as fast as it sounds like with only 50 m/s speed caps on the servers..

Only get this game if it's on ULTRA discount, unless you don't care about multiplayer.

Singleplayer runs pretty well, multiplayer is hell and WILL make you MAD many, many times.

Graphics are very nice, it's just the optimization part, playing on dedicated servers makes you rather want to walk on a contraband in real life than watch it happen in-game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFor quite some time, I had to say the Space Engineers was one of the more fun sandbox games that you could get in a self-hosted multiplayer fashion, but over time the developers have really dropped the ball. The game's weekly updates have been steady, and new features added constantly, but stability has been an absolute nightmare due to the apparent focus on feature creep and lack of developer testing.  Releases are almost always followed by immediate patches for widespread gamebreaking issues, mods are broken often, and there is no apparent interest from the developers in moving to a slower and more stable approach. The game may be in Early Access, but developers should never use this as a reason to provide absolutely zero quality testing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright so due to a recent impulse of negative reviews I want to clear up a few things about SE.
ONE, it is in (Beta), and has one of the most active development base in all of steam and early access.
Also, the main features have been added, and optimization is the next step, the game has gotten SO MUCH BETTER since it
first came out, and people complain about the performance after the planetary release, this was a huge feature.
The game uses a lot of computing for mapping out and modifing a massive planet, so there is a pretty big load on your
PROCESSORS, this game doesn't need a badass GPU, it needs a pretty good CPU to run smoothly. The Network coding is being completely restructured, so obviously it is going to take awhile to be sufficent, but it WILL be better than it was before. All in all, this is a great creative game that is great for you if you have a good rig and love other creative survival games like Rust, Minecraft, DayZ, H1Z1, etc.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As always, buying a game that is still in early stages of development is a risky move. It was not without hesitation that I bought this game, and that was even at a 50% sale. Well, after the three first days I had amassed an impressive ~30 hours of playtime simply because I couldn't stop playing!

It should be said that I have not put much time at all into the Survival mode, I've almost exclusively been playing Creative mode. If you even consider buying this game I advise you to check Youtube for gameplay videos - there are lots of channels that give you a good perspective on what this game is, and what you can do within it.

Well, on to some pros and cons!

Pros:
+ Vanilla game offers wonderfull possibilities when it comes to construct your ships and bases.
+ The modding community is outstanding and expands vastly on the vanilla game.
+ The Dev-team seems to update the game in regular intervals. (They even released a major one on X-mas day!)
+ In my opinion fairly cheap for what you get.
+ Out of ideas for what to build? Youtube is full of incredible channels that feature user created content from Space Engineers that continue to inspire for a long time.
+ The ability to save your designs and paste" them into new world. This is togglable when you create a new world.
+ Easy to get started with and a world of more complex constructs awaits you if you dive deeper into the game.

Cons:
- The maximum travel speed ingame might feel pretty slow if you are playing on a large world with long distances to cover.
- Game is still in a pretty early development stage
date: so bugs and glitches are bound to be around for a while.\n- Public multiplayer can seem infested by griefers unless you are playing with people you know or trust.\n- Easy to spend way too many hours playing
recommended: forgetting other stuff like sleeping or eating...\n\nTo conclude this review
hoursPlayed:
I would like to say that I most heartily recommend this game to anyone who wants to let loose their creative side when building awesome stuff in space.

Just my few cents!
/Trobbel"

Early Access Review

Good:  Deeply engrossing.  Unique perspective.  Excellent physics.  Not a Minecraft clone.

Bad:  Frustrating and confusing interface (this is coming from a Total War / Europa Universalis fan).  Unreasonable learning curve.  Streamline the messy menus, and add a decent tutorial.  You lose a lot of people within the first few hours of the game.  Like you did me, at first.

Conclusion:  Fantastic idea.  Implementation needs significant improvement, but the base mechanics are great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm more addicted to this game than Minecraft lately. When my friends are off doing their thing in games I don't have, I'm usually in this. I'm only just scratching the surface of potential, too. Creative if insanely fun, and Survival is harshly challenging. If you want more challenge in either mode, the recent addition of Meteor storms has seriously kicked things up a notch. If you feel the need you can change your world settings from Survival to Creative, you can change the frequency of Meteor showers, and adjust the realism of Survival if you're having a hard time with the masochistic default survival settings.

Not a true Sandbox game yet, but I imagine that is a possibility in the future. The plyable objects and terrain is also fun, you can drill into things, blow it apart with rockets, or stockpile warheads and set it all on fire!

I left out that I found the Music rather fitting and epic, but to summarize the rest: Buy this game if you like building things and space ships. It's still in-dev so there's definitely more to come!

-Addendum 10/10/2014 GET THIS WHILE IT'S ON SALE! This game is PERFECT for the creative minds out there and the people who enjoy space sandboxes. It has it's limits still for me, but once I get a new computer I intend on writing a completely new review. Play it while you can and try and get it while it's on sale!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Due to early access, this review is subject to change. Also, I noticed a ton of childish reviews that really have not been helpful at all, I hope to fix this.

A decent building sim, but if you are looking for anything other than a simple building sim with literally nothing else to do other than mining for ore, and building structures/ships then don't buy this. Once you build all your ships and structures, there is really nothing to use these creations for. The game gets extremely tedious and the optimization is not absolutely great. The game requires a pretty powerful pc in order to get satisfactory gameplay online. I personally have not played single player, so I do not know how that is. I realize this is still early access but in comparison to some other early access titles, this one is virtually unplayable if you are anything like me, and don't own a great graphics card or powerful processor. I can run any of the games in my library no problem at medium - high settings, but not this game.

As you can see, I have put many hours into this game so it IS fun, but that is based solely on the idea that you think there just HAS to be more to the game, or more is coming and once you reach the point I have, of realizing what the game truly consists of, you are left thinking how pointless it is to play. The updates are frequent, usually every Thursday but in the year I have owned it, not too much has been changed in terms of giving us some actual substance. There is literally nothing to do other than mine, and craft. You can try to have big epic space battles with your friends, but unfortunately combat scenarios are very laggy and not only that, if you are playing in survival, you don't really want to destroy your creations so quickly. I would personally love to be able to USE my creations for something other than mining or capturing an empty stray ship for more ore. All in all, this game has potential, but in it's current state, unless you want a simple building sim with not much else to focus on, this one is NOT for you. If you want a true online experience I suggest waiting till they add more content.


CONS:

-  The optimization is not GREAT. The game requires a pretty powerful rig to get the most out of the experience.

- Lack of things to do. All there is to do, is build and mine for ore/collect resources. Gets very tedious and repetitive, extremely quickly.

- No player progression whatsoever. (This is more of a personal con as I feel this would improve the overall game, but to each his/her own.)

- Should be $10 considering it's current unfinished state.

PROS:

- Great concept

- Beautiful atmosphere

- An abundance of things to craft with and create.

- Multiplayer (Would be cooler, if there was some sort of common goal, or struggle. Something to create strife, as there is nothing to really do.)

- Extremely frequent updates, and devs who seem to care.

All in all, it's a game with lots of potential but it is very tedious and boring in it's current state. I would suggest waiting, unless you want something to literally just build ships that you can't really use for anything other than taking screenshots and showing them off.

I played for a bit, seems pretty solid. It was off to a rocky start but then the devs started pumping iron and breathed life into the empty void. It started to pick up traction shortly after but that was nothing compaired to the shipments of updates that started flying by. I'm really impressed by how clear the devs vision of what they want the game to be is, its astronomical. Communication has always been a focus of the devs when constructing the backbone of the game: its community. Shortly after I started playing this game the community exploded due to all the direct comms between the community and the devs. I still can't beleive how un-survivable the ordeal started out as only to become the most airtight experience I've had on steam. They've really refined the game into a masterpeice and merged the collective ideas of the community with the pressurized determination of the most productive, effective, and efficient development team I've ever discovered in my adventures.








What are you looking for? More puns? Shoo, nobody likes it when you project your wants unto them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Came back to this game yesterday after quiting a few months ago.  Spent last night and today playing and realised why I quit in the first place.  The game is VERY buggy and nothing is being done about it.  The same bugs that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off more than a year ago are still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off today.

For example, you spend hours working on a ship, things are looking good, and then randomly the ship starts twitching and the landing gear explode, sending the ship far out into space, never to be seen again, hours down the drain.

most recently I logged onto my game and my ship just blew up while being rendered,  note that I was playing on single player, so no time had elasped since I last played.  My ship was fine one second, and just blew up for no reason the next.

The latest planet update is the next big debacle,  I only tried to play on a planet for about ten minutes before I gave up: planets have the worst lag and framerate ever, the games optimization is already bad, but just forget about it on the planets.

I love the concept of space engineers, and it was a lot of fun when it wasnt making me scream in rage, but seriously devs,  stop adding more features and start fixing the ones that are broken, and I would love to recommend this game, but until then I will not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me preempt this by saying this is from a multiplayer perspective.

The game, while beautiful and full of promise, is currently a broken pile of chips.

For the past month we spent every Tuesday on this for hours (with vods if you must see for proof) full of broken physics, stupid deaths and suicidal AI.  And the planets, while awe-inspiring, are only that way ‘til you ‘land’ on them.

My deaths have been many and glitchy...and since this game doesn't keep items on either death or relog, they can be detrimental if you were trying to build something and had items in hand.  Oh, let me say that last bit again, just to be clear: on relog, if you have items in hand, they are GONE.  So I hope you put your stuff away, 'cause what you had is poof!  But I digress...let's actually look at my experiences!

My last deaths are as follows:
- Walked into a tunnel, touched a pebble.  Fell through the earth to my doom.
- Walked up to an AI ship that crashed into the surface, jittering wildly...got touched by it, almost died from the contact (okay, not technically a death, but close).
- Used a jetpack to fly up to a mountain top, couldn’t slow down, crashed.
- Same, but tried landing on smooth surface.
- Walked across the ice.  That’s it.  Was walking across the ice.  The flattest, most benign surface you could imagine.  Tripped on NOTHING and died.
- Reloaded server, couldn’t move on spawn...slowly suffocate to death.  REPEATEDLY.

This is not to account for the multiple times I ended up somehow falling into the center of the planet from touching a pebble...those don’t count as deaths because I’d have to teleport up to a fellow player (I count one because I didn’t have the ability to TP for that one...used backspace).  Just about any physics object can easily become a glitchy mess...I saw breakdancing vehicles, floating body bags and playing kickball with a ship...before suffocating inside where the ship ACTUALLY was.  Oh, and don't try actually digging down into the earth...you know, where everything is, because trying to point DOWN and hitting the rock with your actual drill is near impossible!  And this is supposedly the EASIEST way to mine right now.  This is all very recent, and after a week of ‘fixes’ for planets.

And about those planets...I foresee further issues once it’s realized that the planets have indestructible trees, no fluids (water is ice atm), no caves, and a surface devoid of life.  Each one of these things getting eventually added (as I’m sure the populace will demand them) will each in turn break the game yet again.

PLAY EARLY ACCESS AT YOUR OWN RISK.

If and when this game leaves Early Access, I will retry it to see if it is playable, but I assure you...I will NOT be touching this game until that label is removed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Personal Recommendation: Hell Yes!
This game is absolutely amazing.  Yes, there is no real point to it, other than being creative.  Personally, survival is only fun with friends.  It can get somewhat dull otherwise.  This game's only limit is your imagination, if you aren't creative and don't enjoy creative sandbox games, don't get it!  My only complaint is how demanding planets are.  I'm sure they'll optimize in the near future, but it's absultely insane how demanding it is.  I have an i7 4790 and a gtx 960 with 8gb of RAM and I STILL can barely run it at medium settings.  Do I recommend this game?  Yes.  BUT, only to people with good enough computers and how enjoy being creative.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game... I hope someday I can change this review to positive but honestly its been
years now and perhaps there have been a few optimizations but it is /still/ a bloody
mess.

Let me start by saying I recently re-downloaded this game, after giving up on it because
rather than optimize the game KSH just decided to raise the minimum system requirements
and I did not meet them. Prior to this I was eagerly awaiting the upcoming optimization,
planets, and new multiplayer back end update. All while suffering through the terribly low
fps and sim speed.

I was really enjoying myself on one of the preset earth-like worlds untill it got so slow that
it became a pain to even play(can we say memory leaks boys and girls? :D)

I've now uninstalled it and given up on it a second time.

I have heard KSH and their legion of fans preach Premature optimization is the root of
all evil." as an excuse for KSH to not optimize their code untill beta. Well let me just
remind them that the /full/ quote is actually:

We should forget about small efficiencies
date:
say about 97% of the time; premature optimization
is the root of all evil

~Donald Knuth

This was born in a time when we still were working with asm. Small efficiencies here literally
meant techniques that would have obfusticated the code base or making various
recommended:
per-cpu-model optimizations for a fractional speed boost. This does not mean make stupid
and wasteful choices while coding. This does not mean ignore plainly obvious bottlenecks in
code (I am certain there must be a few with how bloody slow this game runs). This does not
mean raise the minimum system requirements instead of optimizing the game.

It means write code intelligently
hoursPlayed: which is really not that hard to do if you are capable of\nwriting even basic programs (think basic utilities or really simple GUI without an IDE backing\nyou)
voteText: but don't go nuts on refactoring or writing semi-obfusticated code just to reduce\nprocessing a small amount. It means attach a profiler
helpfulPercent: determine where the real hogs are
votesHelpful:
and address them instead.

I acknowledge that beta is a time of bug fixing and optimization. But that is precisely the
time for optimization of the little things
votesTotal:
which is exactly what Knuth was referencing.
Fixing the bugs and optimizing the systems is something that should be done the /entire/
time.

As I said
votesFunny: I have nothing but a few minor issues with the actual game itself (cyberdogs are\none of these issues for being so out of place and immersion breaking)
commentsCount:
but the VRage
engine is a trashy mess currently and ruins the game for me and several others I know.
I /really/ hope that I can actually run this game some day!

Thanks to whomever reads this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't know where to start with this review. With nearly 200 hours, I can say I fell into this game with a Minecraft level addiction. It's been sitting in my library unplayed for a while because the game seemed to lack any real goal, or formal challenge. This changed when they implemented planets.

My first and only real run at SE lasted pretty much the bulk of my playtime. Not having any real reason to play the game up until that point. But this go-round I instituted my own goal; I would crash on a planet in a starting ship, I'd get off planet and build an orbital base, from the base I'd build a ship that'd allow me to travel to another planet.

Not a complicated goal, but it kept my interest in the game up. I had just gotten the step where I build my own ship, a mobile base it you may. By that time I had left my orbital base to explore. I had a half-build mothership, a mining ship, and a ship for landing planet-side.

I decided to leave my base behind and explore since I now had functioning thrusters, and even better, a warp drive. However, as I moved around my mothership, I noticed some really strange things happening with my docked ships when I moved my mothership. While staying docked they'd still manage to shift in my hangar hull.

Well that was kinda annoying. After nearly every jump and every ship repositioning (even after lowering my gyro power to 2%, as I thought that might be doing it) I had to go back to my hanger and re-dock my ships.

Anyway, after hours and hours of work, I've given up on the game. Last night I left my ship saved right after a jump heading towards the moon. When I logged back in, I was dead, and my ship was hurling through space at about 42 m/s with no explanation. It was stopped when I saved last night. Sorta, I noticed more and more after I'd jump somewhere that my ship would 'drift' even after inertia dampening it back down to no thrust, it'd accelerate back up to 0.01 m/s.

After having to respawn twice and do some quick jetpack work, I was able to get my ship stopped. My mining ship is gone, my lander is destroyed and my hangar has a huge hole in it. No explanation. Hours of work destroyed by a bug.

Like any early access game, wait till it's released.

UPDATE: 06/02/2016 Gave it a try again, spent a considerable amount of time building until eventually I had two unwarranted ice explosions. Containers full of ice in two ships spontaneously exploded. This game is still not ready for prime-time. I'd recommend steering clear of it.

I'd suggest not buying it at all. I doubt it will ever be fixed.

I doubt I'll be trying it again. I was also greatly looking forward to Medieval Engineers, I can say with all certainty that I will be passing on it completely. From the mostly negative reviews it's currently getting, I guess it's not a huge surprise.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlright, close your eyes and picture Minecraft. Now, replace the pixelated visual style with crisp graphics that rival Bioware titles. Good, now replace the medieval fantasy setting with the depths of space. Then, add the physical properties associated with space, and a building mechanic that not only lets you build architecture, but also space craft ranging in size from small fighters to gargantuan carrier vessels. Add blocks of various shapes and components for complicated mechanisms such as motors and gravity generators. Let's also throw in a destruction engine that lets every block deform with stress and damage in the most realistic manner conceivable. What you'll have is the wet dream of every creative gaming enthusiast, only this isn't a dream.
voteText: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

With only 50 hours in this game, I'll base my review on what I've learned so far.

Build Stations
Build Ships
Loose ship cuz you didn't realize it needed to be stuck to Landing Gear while building
Create weird and complex structures
Die cuz you forgot to recharge energy
Take your first flight, loose the ship cuz you forgot thrusters somewhere
Redesign your ship to get more weird things on.
Make your first LARGE ship
Start dreaming of controlling your own Serenity, Enterprise or an Klingon Battlecruiser.
Play around with Rotors, Pistons, commmand blocks and more to make it even cooler....


Watch the tutorials :D .. The first hour I spend not understanding what to do at all! As the super tech guy I am ( I thought ) .. This was no prob to play. .. untill I actually started it.
Back on the tutorials to get the basic, then on youtube to watch some tips and tricks, and now ... now the game is just awsome.

I'm trying out new ways to build ships, trying my best to make copies of ships like X-Wing, Serenity and more.
Building a space station, and just make it bigger .. more complex way to utilize the station .. just to see where it takes me .. I love every aspect of it.

It does have bugs .. all games do .. This is an Early Alpha .. remember this.
The bugs that are in Creative mode is  more as small hickups .. the funny glitch when you mine something, and suddenly you see through the whole asteriode for a second, then return to the mining again .. can be weird, fun and annoying .. all at once :D
In survival mode I've had one bigger issue .. and it was that my miningship sometimes just broke during flight .. or lost a container or reactor .. once I lost 5 thrusters ... but ... even as annoying this is, I recommend NOT using the autosave .. but rather save at your own so you can get back and redo if you crash or loose something due to a glitch.

I have only a few hours in multiplayer, so I will not comment much regarding this. The little I've played have been flawless. I would believe that some of the survival mode glitches might appear in MP survival aswell..

Pros:
Total freedom in what you want to build, where to go, what to do.
Grahpics are pretty good. Lots and lots better than minecraft.. ( I know .. stop comparing it lol )
Lots and lots of mods to play around with.
You can have a singleplayer survival or creative mode save, and turn it into a LAN/MP world if wanted.
Devs are doing weekly updates, from new items/armor and more, to bugfixes and optmizing.

Cons:
You get thrown into space, not much help there. ( unless you watch tutorials and youtube )
Glitches and bugs, but this is a part for ALL games...
Unless you KNOW what an item does, there's no helpscreen about the item. ( example: you have rotor, but unless you know what to do, you won't get it to work right... )

But!!! All in all. .. I'm very happy I got this game gifted to me. So far I have enjoyed my 50 hours into the game, an I know I will enjoy atleast the next 100 hours. Unless I have figured out how to use ALL things ingame, I will keep playing and playing.

I've already made a 10 player dedi server for me and my friends to play on :D

10/10
Go get it :D
