reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space engineers is simply a fantastic game for the gamer who is into creation in a sci-fi atmosphere. Basically, the point of the game is single/group/multiplayer (vs) survival (or sandbox) creation of ships and stations in space. Player vs. player combat is virtually nonexistent, as the point of the game is to create ships and bases to do the combat for you. The building possibilities are relatively endless, as new parts are added with each update. It is somewhat 'HD Minecraft'-esque in that all parts are geometric (though the asteroids are not). It is rather graphically demanding for the texture quality, however this is somewhat expected in a game where hundreds of objects  are rendered constantly, at once. The multiplayer experience is so-so, in that private servers are a ton of fun, but public servers ultimately lead to griefing of your structures the moment you log out. There are other space games other there, like KSP, but it is hard to compare the two in a which-is-better way, as their playstyles are far too different.

tl;dr: 8.5/10 Fun sandbox creation game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The alpha that keeps on giving.  Space engineers is a sandbox style game in which you are placed in space and can build to your hearts content.  It shares the same genre as minecraft being a sandbox but is not Minecraft.  Think of it this way, Battlefield is a first person shooter but is in no way the same as Counter Strike.  Sure, each has similarities in that you are in first person mode with a firearm, but beyond that, the mechanics are very different.
Space Engineers takes on this same style.  It seperates itself apart from the rest in that it is in space, is not completely block based, and has a modern/futuristic feel to it that takes some getting used to.  Building is easy in this game, there are many different types of items but the foundation is always a block, slope, inverted corner, triangle, or a landing gear for a ship.  You can make stations, ships, capital ships (larger ships essentially), opening and closing doors, hidden turrets behind a set of lights, etc.  The possibilites are endless and the weekly updates make it even better.
Uranium is your life force and your refinery and assembler are your tools.  Without these three things nothing happens and you end up respawning inside a yellow ship with these basic things and nothing else.  Turning things off like a gravity generator and the engines may be necessary at first just to preserve what little uranium you do have.  Do not fret however, almost all materials needed are not difficult to find...for the most part.  Some places you might find entire sections of uranium while other areas may contain traces of the ore but also have spots of other ore like gold, magnesium, silicon, nickel, iron, and silver.  Each has their uses of course.
Bugs are apparent in some instances of the game.  It is an alpha so it will have issues but as said before, weekly updates are releasing new content and fixing old content that may not work properly.  Dedicated servers are an option or you can just run it from your local machine as you see fit.  The dedicated server that I run is locked down to my group only and consumes very little resources.  In fact, my machine is running a mumble server, a minecraft server, and Space Engineers and the machine is an old AMD Atlhlon x3 x64 system with 4 GB of RAM on windows 7.  So anyone can run a server!
Performance wise, the game engine has a bit of optimization needed.  Sometimes it lags other times it is fine.  I run a very clean system that is top notch performance with dual SSDs in RAID 0 and 16 GB of RAM with dual video cards and a high end processor and still experience issues from time to time.  Nothing serious, but still, they are there.
Overall, the atmosphere of the game is great.  The sound effects, music, graphics, everything is great.  The controls are a bit wonky at first but you get used to them.  You can just remap controls if you really get irritated though, so keep that in mind as an option.  Creative mode and Survival are a blast although the latter is my favorite.  Playing with friends is fun and hunting down those armed mining ships and military ships is a blast.  Physics play a role, so that means mass is also important and how many thrusters you have overall will make a difference.  Everything from reactors to guns and stations to capital ships are present in this game.  Nothing here is poorly executed aside from the menu system which can take some getting used to.  At this point on the timeline, I would say this is a good buy for those looking to play something unfinished but worth their time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AWESOME!!!!!!!! (This was all I could come up with back in Nov 2013, only a month after game release)

Now its nearly May 2016 and I have got over 5200hours playing this game, I still think its awesome.

In the last 2 years or so this game has come a long way from what I remember it was like not long after release. We now have planets to visit and build on as well as a world that is 1Billion K's across to explore. Although, much of it is empty space with asteroids throughout, each and every world can be customised to suit your gaming wishes. There is 100,000's of mods available on the workshop that you can use to make your game experience how you would like it. If you enjoy Star Trek for example, there is many Star Trek themed mods that you could have in your world so you could build the Enterprise or maybe a Klingon Bird of Prey. There is over 200 planets that have been created by the modding community that you could populate your world with.

The choices of gamemodes suit many different players, Single Player Creative mode where you can build whatever you wish without the need for resources. This is a great mode for designing and building ships or stations for blueprint creation for use in other worlds and also learning about all the functions of the many choices of in-game blocks. Single Player Survival, with this gamemode you can challenge yoursef to find the resources you need to build your hopes and dreams. There are several scenarios to choose from, each with differing setups to start a game, for example the Easy Start Scenarios give you a station on a planet with 3 basic ships to get you started in the game. in the setup for each game you can customise the setup to make it however challenging you want. From inventory size, crafting speeds to settings like pirate drones and even cyberhounds and alien spiders which will attack you or start chewing through blocks on your base to get to you.

Then there is multiplayer, you can host your single player game on your own machine to invite friends to join in, or there is many dedicated servers to choose from. I have been running a dedicated server myself for over 2 years now (spaceengineers.com.au). Now, I will be honest and say the multiplayer Netcode is still a WIP and at times, issues in game will frustrate you to no end. Don't let this put a dampner on how you feel about the game, the developers have stuck to their weekly update schedule and slowly but surely everything is getting better. As with all Alpha development games, some patches can end up breaking the game for some, but be patient as the team will surely have the issues patched up soon.

Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building, using and showing off their creations. There is a plethora of player creations on the workshop, including blueprints that other players have created that you can build in game. You are only limited in this game by your own imagination. Search for Space Engineers on youtube too, if this review hasn't been enough to convince you, i'm sure some of the fantastic videos of player creations, machinima and the like would be enough to push you over the edge and make you want to buy it.

Hope to see you in game one day, and if you found this review helpful please give it a thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After I got sick of minecraft, I started looking for a replacement. I bought space engineers a long LONG time ago but never had the ability to play it due to potato PC's. A little later I got a new HP Envy, still was a potoato to run this game. So still was never able to play it. Ever since planets came out made me feel left out because of my PC. I still never touched the game though. After a recent update I decided to give it a try and see what I can get out of it, well since they added the option to turn off shadows really helped! I ran the game on the lowest settings possible, lowered the resolution to the minimum that looked best, not enough to mishape things, still even with the screen. and well I was able to play away!

I managed to get a fast smooth framerate with a Intel HD 4600 GPU!! I would build cool things after I did the tutorial, and would build from little rovers to space stations! I would ask my sister who was very addicted to minecraft: Can you do this in minecraft?!" maybe with all the redstone stuff but would be very bulky.

I don't know why people complain about running this game on beast PC's on low settings and would only get around 10 to 5 fps. I managed to get this game running nice and smooth on a potato! (this is all including planets)

Now people do say that this game is minecraft in space. Well that is accurate. Building is similar to minecraft
date: but more complex. Minecraft is everything blocks. Blocky world too. Space engineers has blocks to smooth out your creations to make them NOT so blocky. The planets are more planet-ish also!\n\nThis game has a high learning curve too. Which I'm sure people don't like
recommended:
but I do! I like to learn how to play complex games like this. Feels really fun and challenging at the same time! After you build some pretty rad things in this game. You'll never complain about your house being griefed on minecraft agiain! :)

The only thing I don't like about this game is that there is not too much to do here. Besides building ships and bases and well stuff like that. Thats why I set my own objectives to reach a certain planet or moon.

I also hear that multiplayer is really buggy. Well I can't say anything about that because I'm more of a anti-social person
hoursPlayed:
so I NEVER play multiplayer. (Unless with a friend)

I also never seemed to encounter much bugs with this game also. (In singleplayer of course) The only bug I have encountered is the gamma or contrast messing up when the game auto saves. (The screen would be really bright or really dark)

Now all I have to say is if you buy this game after reading my review. Keep your expectations low. This is just my expirience with this game and I can't guarentee anything to anyone else.

Thanks for reading this rambling review! It may not prove usefull but It will get my word out!
Thanks again! :)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i can say this game is combination of minecraft and x-albion. basically you need to survive to keep your oxygen supply and station/ship powered. and defend from other players if you're on multiplayer server.

on the first day of survival, you need at least to build your own station. to build and complete this station you need mining the asteroid to get resources(iron, gold, platinum, ice, etc). and then manufacture the necesarry part and combine them into various functionable machines(from assembler, refinery, oxygen generator, reactor etc).

the interesting part begin when you join multiplayer server and compete/coop with other player. you can create turrets to defend your station, fighter ships, capital ships, droid, and warhead torpedo to bombard your oppositions.

i can't wait for the dev to implement planet system. this game have potential to make you able to create your own empire.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Simply amazing, and with the magnitude of updates that comes in each week; with tutorial videos to go along. Just buy it already! Multiplayer is fun, building is a dream with control interfaces that most games wish they had.

The sheer number of items, blocks and designs you can create is staggering! It also has a very nice XYZ mirroring features, copy and paste - real-time of ships and objects. Offensive weapons! Such detailed and rich environment and object / ship damage.

Build big, build small, build a station to house them all! Gravity, Mass, Velocity, etc all apply here and it makes for some great physics fun! With gravity generators, you can make any direction and adjustable field sizing for direct gravity on objects and players. Lighting / shaders are top notch, and the effects you can experience are background / image potential for sure.

It is well worth the money for this, and if you ever want to build together - just shoot me a message!

*This game has only gotten 10x better since my review back in Febuary - customization and amount of addons and changes is too numerous to begin to tell you - the videos on the Store page don't do justice - they are mostly old. Just look up the weekly dev blog that in-depth explains the newest features and keys to get a better feel at current state. The MP is solid and full on space battles are just about seamless.

Wonderful are the latest changes to make ships and stations interchangable with docking ports, and now conveyor systems for item transfers, passenger seating, color scheme on everything is RGB / Hue / Sat customized, Turrets both interior and exterior, artificial mass blocks and gravity generator modifications. I could go on and on, or you could just check out their weekly videos since release. The real-time damage system is SOOO great, and detailed.

There is something for everyone - whether you are into pitting two dogfighters at each other and record it, hundred people in your own spaceport RP system, or simply want to solo design an epic space station in the side of an asteroid you blew a chunk out of.

IF YOU ARE ON THE FENCE AT ALL ABOUT THIS GAME, BUY IT! You will not be sorry.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Lag…

One man dev team can do better, it’s called Starmade.  Get it, its cheaper, and better.

I like so many others, want to like this game.  I've played off and on for quite some time now, waiting for things to be fixed.  Great idea if the game would run right.

Dev's release new gimmicks all the time, cool features even, if it worked.  Multiplayer?  Not really.  False advertising there... multiplayer is super broken.

Many years, much money, and problems this game had at its start are still present.  It looks like a polished game, it's not.  The bugs in this game have prevented me from buying their other one, midevil engineers.  I was worried when they started that project that they were dumping Space Engineers.  It seems devs are working on both with equal incompetence.

DEVS - Stop releasing gimmicks to sell the game and fix the existing game!

PLAYERS - Everyone needs to start posting negative reviews on this game at regular intervals to bring its rating down so it stops selling.  Maybe they will abandon it, maybe they will fix it.  If they stop selling the game, perhaps it will encourage them to do something about the bugs and the total neglect of optimisation.

Would be a great game if it would run on something less than a university super computer and things didn't randomly explode around you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHonestly? THE best early access game i have ever bought. The developers listen to feedback from players e.g. Solar Panels and then later on Rechargable battery packs. It's easiest to describe this game as Minecraft in space" but that doesnt cover it. Minecraft is about setting up a sustainable base and then eventually defeating the Ender-Dragon or in creative mode seeing what you can build using cubes of various materials. Space Engineers is about seeing what you can create using nothing but the resources dug and refined from nearby asteroids
date: making them into various parts for assembly and then constructing anything from makeshift cars to fighter ships all the way up to an Eldar Craftworld (although that will lag a LOT its Early access.. c'mon what would you expect?) The only limit in Space Engineers is your imagination. With an active community that uploads items onto the workshop on a daily basis you can never run out of inspiration or other ships to test your latest deadly weapon or attack vessle against. Apart from the occasional lag issues when your world starts to fill up with failed experiments/enormous ships/enormous space station/ thousands of your corpses cause you failed to recharge your suit in time
recommended: this genuinely feels like a finished product. Except it isn't. With updates coming every week on a Thursday with simple things like Bug fixes or (more often than not) completely new content this is an enjoyable

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is decent if you want to get creative by building ships or pass the time by mining resources, but it has numerous fallthroughs that will likely never be worked on. The game doesn't come together in the way that it should. Animations are clunky, optimization and perfmormance are pretty bad, glitches are very common, and the game structure itself isn't anywhere near user-friendly.

This game cannot be defended by claiming that it's early access. The devs have had plenty of time to polish the weaker aspects of the game, yet seem to lack the insight or skill to address and solve these issues. Instead, their ambition as game developers pushes them to mash in more half-functioning or barely relevant content, which often overcomplicates the game and adds numerous bugs.

Keen Software House has bit off more than they can chew, and it shows when they try to conquer something like planets and AI. The monsters" are of absolute amateur quality

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very fun when it's working as intended, but i can't recommend it for people who want to play it with their friends, which was the main draw for me. The game seems to be a much less bug-ridden experience if you play solo and perhaps in a creative mode, but networked and survival gameplay is very much unpolished.

I've owned this game for years now and i've played it at multiple stages during it's development, which makes me feel like i have a decent grasp on it's issues with it's rate of development and bugfixing, which motivated me to write this review.

I had a lot of fun with this game. I've played it for near 100 hours. After KSP it's probably the best space sandbox game.
But despite all of it's potential i can't really recommend the game, especially as a person who likes multiplayer and playing with friends.

I've always thought that this game was great, but after having it for years i'm not seeing much improvement in terms of bugfixing and networking optimization.
If you want to buy this game, even despite all the bugs, in hopes that the developers will fix it.. I'm saying, don't do it. There is no guarantee that they'll fix anything, since they haven't really fixed any of the core networking issues since i first played the game. Everything is still jumpy, permanently desyncing, crahsing, etc.

The game is ridden with bugs that can break your server unless you clean it up occasionally.
It's also full of bugs that have you or your buddies constantly restarting the game.
Most of the game's issues are networking-related, for example clients not receiving the same information, even at <100 ping, which spirals out of control for some reason, ending at a point where clients may not see interactions of some objects at all, or they see everything 10km away from where it really is. These are really common occurences.
The conveyor system is full of bugs as well, sometimes pulling items in and out of inventories where items shouldn't even be allowed to flow due to the system not being in a loop, just a one way linear set of sorters, cargo boxes and assemblers.

Even though the maximum speed in the game is limited to a grueling 100m/s, supposedly in order to prevent the physics from breaking, it still constantly breaks, while making travel to other planets a journey that takes HOURS unless you mine for just as long of a time for resources to make and use a jumpdrive.

Starting scenarios are kind of a mess as well, there is no option to just start in a star system with asteroids and limited resources, essentially allowing you to play a survival mode where you can't spawn in new ships. There are some scenarios but they may not include some other generated features of the game. So you either modify server settings on the fly, or tweak your world with the editor in order to have a non-creative, survival experience with all the generated feautres (planets/moons/asteroids) of the game.
If you are completely new to the game you may miss out on these features entirely if you just start one of the scenarios that seem good.

I have the most stable computer i've ever had, reaching 10 weeks of uptimes regularily while playing games and using various heavy applicatios.
I don't think any game has ever crashed my system consistently since i've built my rig 2-3 years ago, yet space engineers manages to do it 2 times in an hour.

So, in closing... People who have played DayZ can understand a situation like this, where the game can be SO FUN yet so RIDDLED with bugs even after years of development, which is what makes this game really hard to recommend, because i DO want to play games with friends.
The DayZ developers worked with a proprietary engine that is very much known to be bug-ridden.
I'm not sure what the excuse of Keen Software House is, as they've been working this engine engine from the ground up, starting with their previous games.
Now they're also working on a game called medieval engineers...?
Why?

Early Access Review

This is an extremely bugged out alpha game that will give you hours of severe frusteration as you build a massive ship only to have a bug detonate all the ordinace on board and leave a gaping hole in your beloved weapon of mass destruction.

With that said... It is truly the most awesome game I have had to pleasure to experience.  When things are working the possibilities are endless.  The final refined version of this game may very well redefine MMO and sandbox style gaming.  When you loot something you really LOOT SOMETHING.  The idea that when you kill someone you can truly take EVERYTHING THEY HAVE and use it to build your stuff.  People will be building secret bases and uber defenses around every corner to avoid being the next victim of player vs player perma death raiding.  Of course there are different rules for different servers so you can find the one that suits your style and enjoy.

Did I mention I decided to rename my oldest son Keen?

Thank you Space Engineers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a relative newcomer to this game (only a month or so) so I've avoided a lot of the growing pains. As it stands now, especially with the latest patch that introduces drones and pirate bases, I can't recommend the game enough for anyone interested in 1) space 2) designing spaceships/bases with intricate details 3) survival. I've been gaming for decades and can't think of another game that made me feel so proud of my creations. The first time I designed a capable mining ship, with conveyors, spotlights, connectors, etc., and the damn thing actually WORKED as intended, well, I just had to pop open a cold one and pat myself on the back :) I've moved on to designing a capital ship now and relish the design challenges involved, such as maximizing Internal space while keeping weight manageable and finding a good protection/speed balance. So many challenges... It really gives you the feeling of being an actual engineer without the pesky 4-years-in-university part.

In addition to the basic game, many of the mods available through the workshop are true works of art, and easily double the number of blocks available. The introduction of AI enemies is still in its infancy but already promises to become something special, especially given KSH's investment in developing AI. The only thing I really miss at this point is the fact that my Oculus DK2 is not fully supported (can be played with VorpX but it kinda sucks).

Yes, there are some bugs (notably sometimes a slowdown in framerates when you mine)but, overall, I can say that I'm happy I paid full price for this game. It was money well spent and the devs deserved every penny of it.

Space Engineers for the Average Joe Gamer:

Purchase: Sweet! Found this on sale/finally got this game, it looks wicked cool!

Main Menu: Hmm... Might go on single player first just so I know what to do before I get pwned in multiplayer...
*starts up single player world*

*5 minutes go by*

In game: Woo! That took a while, must be a big world!
*touches mouse*
LAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAG SPIKE
Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah! Make it stop, please!
*deals with it once computer finally manages to hit 10 fps*
Alright, hmm, what to do...
*finds spaceship*
Ooooooooh! Sick, how do you fly this thing?
*Searches 5 minutes before the cockpit's found*
Phew, made it. Let's go!
*Enters cockpit and flies around*
Sick! Look at me, ma... WAIT? ARE THOSE GUNS ON MY SHIP?!?!? HOW DOES GUNS BLAM?!?!?
*spends 10 minutes pressing buttons in the hopes that they do something*
Meh... YouTube/Forums.
*Quits game, spends next 2 hours on YouTube/Forums looking for instructions that make sense*
Ah, ha! Everything is mine now!
*Restarts game with all its laggy glory*
Meh he he...
*Gets in spaceship with intentions of decimating anything that exists*
*Fires 1 rocket*


*5 minutes of lag later*



boom.

... WAT.

11/10 Would lag for mediocre explosion again

Early Access Review

tl;dr 12/10

Never compare this game to any other early access product. This is something beyond the
- A list of features is growing continiously. Every feature is not just a feature to mentoin, but a thing YOU will use.
- Sandboxiest sandbox. Create space stations, large and small ships. Become an artist, a designer and an engineer.
- Computer systems of the future. Every block that have computer component in it will fight on your side until destroyed, unpowered or hacked. Create a defense system that will kill anyone trying to sneak into your base, while keeping your base open to your friends and their ships.
Create manned, automated remote-controlled systems.
- Every block count. Everything you see is not a decoration, but a fully working part of system.
- Survival. Mine asteroids, explore space and survive meteor storms.
- More and more things to tell
- Limitless amount of situations and space traffic accidents.
- More cool things coming! Upgrade your old ships with brand new blocks from new updates.

Also you could try Miner Wars 2081 - http://store.steampowered.com/app/223430/
not a best game, but it shares the same spirit with space engineers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Stay far away unless you are content to build alone in creative mode only.

I purchased this game June 2014.  As of this writing, that was 1 1/2 years ago.  The game is so bugged now that I cannot even stomach launching it any more.  Let me explain..

I have a deep love for the concept and great hope that KSH can pull this game together.  When I first purchased it, I played solo survival for a month and had a blast.  I then moved on to survival multiplayer PvP and had some of the most thrilling fulfilling gameplay of any game ever.  I made a dozen new friends, had factions and teams.. what a truly wonderful time.

But as time progressed, the Thursday patches became less of a anticipated feature gift and more of plea not to kill the game with crushing bugs.  After 6 months of almost completely killing the multiplayer community, the remaing few of us left in abject sorrow.  We could no longer play the game we loved so much.

2015 came and went with dozens upon dozens of new features.  Great for the solo creative crowd, and kudos to KSH for keeping such a brisk pace.  But as 2015 closes, multiplayer is still unplayable.  The few server owners cry on the KSH forum for help just keeping their servers from crashing after 30 minutes.  A whole year and zero progress on MP.

I will absolutely return to this game if KSH ever gets MP working.  Until then, it is in the what could have been" category.

And I will absolutely never ever purchase another Early Access game.  Developers have no incentive to ever finish the game
recommended: and be accountable for its performance."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEdit 7 April 2016: Went back last week and started a new SE game after throughly enjoying Empryion Galactic Survival (big thumbs up for EGS!) the last couple months. Space Engineers hasn't changed. Still broken; pistons, wheels, power 'grid' still broken, etc. Hand mining after Empryion's much better system is incredibly bad in SE. Very very short interaction distance means lots of grief/frustration and due to still broken 'moveable bits' like wheels & pistons, trying to make a working mining truck is hopeless. NPC/PvE is -so- much better in Empryion! SE's idea of PvE on starting 'Earth' are jihadist exploding 'dogs' that would make Isis seem like a sweet old grandmother. Pointlessly OPed. Still have to engineer -around- the game" not -with- the game. Some simple things that Empryion got right and SE devs seem too depressed to even consider; EGS uses Hovercraft instead of wheeled starter vehicles (hovers work great in EGS)
date: Empryion has elevator blocks to get up & down (and they work when un-powered!) SE just has ramps. EGS starting survival is very nicely balanced with well done Hunger/Health/Oxygen systems
recommended:
and NPCs -add- to immersion & are useful to boot.
Bottom line: I can easily recommend Empryion at full price but can't bring myself to recommend SE even at this weekends sale price of $7.49.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still haven't played enough to explain why this game is truly the best in it's class.

Jokes aside, this game is magnificent. With weekly updates and a development team that really cares about what the players want, few can compare.

A short list of things you can do:
=========================
* Build a space fairing bohemoth of a vessel to explore the universe.
* Build space stations to replicate any sci-fi metropolis of your dreams.
* Build a small ship that can even take a family of 4. (But you don't have one... because you're in space...)
* Become the CEO of a space mining conglomerate with a legion of AI programmable drones at your disposal (Once you've built them of course).
* Have a soul searching journey into the depths of space. (Hans Zimmer track not included)
* Colonise an asteroid
* Colonise a moon
* Colonise a Planet!
* Have a bundu bash on said moon or planet. (Seriously these things are huge! Planets have an average diameter of 120 km.)
* Build a fort and protect it against invading AI like pirates or sabiroids.
* Enjoy the vistas of these different worlds
* Settle down on your favorite space rock.
* Make a weapon using gravity generators and artificial mass blocks.
* Play multiplayer with your friends so you can build, explore, raid and fight pirates together.
* Go on servers and enjoy the different game setups available.
* Torment your friends with the gravity weapon you made.
* Lose your friends...
* And find them again using a well built communication relay. (Once you've built that as well)
* Just kidding I still haven't found them, I just like to fly around in my intergalactic space ship (I designed it myself. Let me show some of the different lengths of wire I used.)
* Write a review to praise it's ingenuity. (Just like I did right now, yay)

This isn't for the faint-of-hearted when it comes to sandbox games though, but the final payoff with any project is always awe-inspiring.

Also with the addition of planets as well as other goodies like a thriving modding community, you can customize your game according to your taste.

This game isn't a virtual world, it's a virtual universe!

Honestly, buy this game, get your friends to buy it too. Space sure is quiet without a familiar voice.

If I could give a numeric score it would be the same as the possibilities this game possesses:
∞/∞ (Apply L'Hospital... or not)

TL;DR - This game is REALLY great, buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this writing, no. It's a glorified tech demo. A very well done tech demo, but nothing more. If you think I'm being harsh, let me explain.

First of all, there's very little to actually do. Planets are an unfinished, glitchy feature with lots of half-baked ideas shoved into them. Ship to ship combat is... There, but there's no real point to it. There's no auto-repair systems and the structure of your ship is tinfoil, so unless you're fighting in creative (You know, being a child smashing his toys together) you'll spend maybe a minute trying to shred an enemy and the next two hours patching holes in your hull and replacing damaged equipment. True, there is survival, and early game survival is fun, but sooner or later one of two things will happen.

If you're playing with the enemies disabled, you will struggle to find power and oxygen. Resource managment is gonna be difficult. A minor mistake in piloting a mining ship will cost you dearly. It's actually pretty tense and you'll have to think about how to survive... But then you'll tip. You'll build a bigger base, then a bigger ship, and you'll feel accomplished. Then you'll upscale again. Then again. Then again. Resources are no longer an issue, so it now becomes a case study in how much of a pain in the ♥♥♥ welding every single hull plate of a capital ship can be.

If you're brave enough to play with enemies on, you will die. The resources required to make even small arms ammunition are scarce. Very scarce. Every time I've ever played I built building-sized mining vessels before I had bullets for my rifle. That might actually be an interesting choice if the enemies appeared when you met some abitrary condition, but they don't. If you're in space, a big Argevantis cruiser is gonna show up and raze everything you spent hours building because there's no way you can adequately defend yourself against it. If you're on planets, have fun, because space spiders and cyberhounds are going to rip you a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as soon as you land.

But I'll join a cooperative ser-" No you won't. In a game as horifically glitchy as this

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My rule is never buy early access games. Only exception is beta versions. Its kind of like flushing your loved ones down the toilet. Yes, I was talking about money. Well, i blame steam sales. Actually, never buy early access games, unless steam sales, and pricing under 10 bucks.

After barely five hours......
Like most people here, I really like what i see. Even though some may find it tideous, the game makes you WANT to build and explore. And with the co-op with friends or anyone, it makes up for a rather exciting game. If this game also get a broader and more intriguing npc factions, wildlife with both grass eaters and predators, heck maybe even fishes....it could become a great game indeed. It certainly have potential. Forget then about all those silly zombie survival games that also never vill be finished....

There seems to be huge graphichs issues with this game. At 1920 x 1080, with a Radeon HD 7870, I have to put everything to low, to have liveable framerates. Says a lot about this game, considering its not exactely high fiedlity in graphics. As a comparison, Battlefield 4 plays with everything on high at 2560 x 1440 or something like that. Also there seem to be a bug with saving game? Game only saved when i use Save as". Like most early access games
date: I wouldnt exactely bet on them to finish it. But atleast I hope they iron out excisting bugs.\n\nI recomend this game if you dont mind to flush you loved ones down the toilet. Or if its on steam sales for max 10 bucks. Else
hoursPlayed: dont waste money."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to be straight forward here: This game started out so promising.. and has now devolved to the point where I don't even think they're putting much effort into it anymore. They are literally adding modding tools so modders can actually finish their game (after Keen made so much money out of it and modders didn't).

The last few updates have been virtually worthless unfortunately.

After Keen broke Survival MP again during the Christmas holidays, which was fixed an entire week later rather than doing a rollback on the spot, they added suicide dogs no one asked for, only to now break Survival MP again, with, again, something that could have been tested by three guys logging into a test server for 5 minutes. So now we gotta wait, again, potentially an entire week, until we can play Survival MP.

Sadly a great idea in the hands of very limited minded people.

I do not recommend this game at this stage, they are launching updates every week but useless ones, not real bug fixes or optimization. Just adding stupid features and modding tools so people can finish what they don't care anymore.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most fun i've had playing a game in a really long time. Make sure to set all the settings to max if you get bored easily. At 1x speed it can quickly turn into an eve online snorefest.. but at 10x it really picks up. You don't need a lot of players on a server to be fun as 1v1 combat is enjoyable. The crafting and destructable environment / physics / graphics are an amazing addition to a block building game.

The game is in alpha so there are bugs and a bit of sync issues on multiplayer, but avoidable. The game updates every thursday on the dot, and the devs interact and listen to what the players want. A must have game if you have ever played Kerbal/Eve Online/Minecraft.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is not minecraft in space. Ok so now that we have that out of they way, Space Engineers is a great game if you want to create ships with guns and blow stuff up. In its current state the multiplayer is playable but sometimes abit buggy, but that is to be expected from an alpha state. The game offers two modes, Creative and Survival. In creative mode you can build what ever you want with no need to collect resources, this is good if you just want to build some wonderfull ships. The Survival mode is just what its name suggests, unlike Creative mode you have to actually mine resources to build parts in this mode. In my personal opinion Survival mode is best played with friends as playing it alone can become boring very fast, but with friends it is very enjoyable and fun. The game is updated every Thursday which is nice as it is something to look forward to.
In final review I would give this game in its current state a 8.9/10, it would have been a 10 if not for some multiplayer problems, but as I said the game is updated regually so prehaps these issues will be fixed soon.
I hope this review was helpfull.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a phenomenal example of how the Early Access program can be a real positive addition to the Steam ecosystem. The developers seem to be on top of this project and show a lot of passion for the game and even more for the players they are building this game for.

I suppose it's inevitable that this game be called Minecraft in space, and while it's hard to argue that this is not an appropriate description I feel that it doesn't do this title justice. Space Engineers isn't just a rubbish Minecraft knockoff with a space skin on it; from the beginning this game was developed to stand on it's own as a sandbox, spacemining, crafting and combat simulator.

The game, in it's current state, is fully functional; I cannot say the optimization is the best as of the writing of this early impressions but updates are frequent and content is still pouring in. I think for most people you're just as well off to wait until at least beta because I can see the content becoming stale for those who go in with just a mild interest in the idea of the game, however if you're a fan of sandbox gameplay and really love space, you won't regret picking up Space Engineers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updates come out every thursday evening like clockwork, and each week makes the game better.
What with planets and DX11 in the pipeline this game is promising to be something truly amazing.

I can understand that a lot of people have trust issues with alpha releases and developers, but the guys at KSH really have done a stellar job, and have kept up a consistently good job for nigh on two good years with this game, it has got to the point now where, if they promise something, I trust them to stick to it.

However, it is very important that when people buy this they remember that this is still alpha, and as a result optimisation in both single and multiplayer has not been tackled yet, and hence larger online servers are rather unstable and filled with many occurences of rubberbanding, or lag, although with a complete re-write of multiplayer on the way I can see these issues soon being a thing of the past.
I see buying into this game not for it's playability factor now, but as an investment.

Even so at it's current stage the game is more than worth the money they ask, with basically infinite creative possibilities single player is fun and can eat hundreds of hours into building things that look really great, and in multiplayer small 'race to eliminate the other team' competitive servers with a few friends are one of the most fun experiences I've actually had with a game.

All in all, even if you don't feel like its an amazing game now, (which it is by all means) check back every now on then on the KSH forums, see what they've added, see what's on it's way, because this game really does get better every week.

Early Access Review

8/10A really great game about building beautiful ships. AND THEN CRASH 'EM
No, but seriously, this game is awesome!

Cons:
- now in early access a bit lonely

So I still think, really buy this game, give it a try. The price is really worth it, it's fun, you can get creative, and its potential seems to be used by the developers of this game very well. They don't add some crap nobody needs, but they add what really helps the game getting completed one day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the lifetime of the game thus far.  Early Access is understandable, and things are going to break and become buggy.  Everyone that's buying EA games should know this, and it's written as disclaimers in a lot of games prior to even playing it.

The Developers of this game have always operated under the idea that people want content, and more content they shall have.  I don't believe this is actually to please their fanbase, but it's more of an in house quota that they're trying to meet as a business.

I am not recommending this game to anyone that's currently thinking about purchasing this game.  I am also recommending that anyone who has played this game for a relatively long time that has written a review, or is thinking about writting a review to give your true honest opinion for whether or not you recommend this game given the track record of the company.

I will say the cliche thing that you read time and time again, I really want to recommend this game and give it a positive review
date: but with it's current state I feel I cannot."  However
recommended: the current state that is being referenced is not just this weeks most recent Forced Update (the game needs PATCHES
hoursPlayed: not updates) but more so how this game has been pumped with more content than it can currently handle given the underlying bugs from previous content pushes.\n\nI will change my review at a later date if the KeenSWH developers start polishing up the current state of the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unfortunately I have to side with those suggesting that you carefully consider before buying.  At this point it seems to me:

1. there are too many bugs left in, or added via new releases
2. have no idea when / if will leave early access and be bugless and finished
3. mining and building in it is fun and certainly the pinnacle of what it offers now when the bugs don't send you awry, but it seems Empyrion has quickly eclipsed it in playability if you want to build things like hover vehicles, spacecraft and base stations and is less buggy, or, if you want space flight, combat, trading, mission objectives with less construction and instead can live with just customizing space vehicles as you pick and choose your way through a wide variety of spacecarft with customizable components and optimizations for different ways of playing, Elite Dangerous is way ahead and Star Citizen is supposed to be on our side of the horizon this year.

So, at this point Elite Dangerous has stolen what time I might have continued to put into SE to get my outer space Star Trek fix and it's hard imagining they catch up to reach a level of playability that's more fun than the competition is already at.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is awesome. It's better on creative mode, but I like it either way. This is a physics game that has easier physics. So for a normal guy just having fun like me, it's awesome. You mine for ores, smelt them to bars, build components, and build blocks with those components, and you can build your ship however you want. Frigets, cargo ships, drop ships, orbital bombers, orbital gravity canons, stationary gravity canons, giant compounds, ANYTHING. Your immagination is the limit, or well, the game makers immagination is the limit. You can also download ships that other peolpe made and spawn them in your game, and you can download character skins too.

PROS: PHYSICS
SPACE SHIPS
BUILDING AWESOME SHIPS
CRASHING AWESOME SHIPS
FLYING AWESOME SHIPS
SPACE
GUNS
BOMBS
ROCKET LAUNCHERS
ALIENS
KILLING
MULTIPLAYER
FIGHTING
NPC BASES
BLOWING STUFF UP
AWESOMENESS
FUN

CONS: PHYSICS
SURVIVAL IS HARD
CRASHING AWESOME SHIPS WHEN YOU DON'T WANT TO
THERE IS A SPEED LIMIT... IN SPACE
GRAVITY CANONS DON'T WORK LIKE THEY SHOULD, BUT ARE STILL GOOD
THINGS RANDOMLY EXPLOAD

IN CONCLUSION, This game is awesome. I think this is a great and fun game. This game does make space joy ride, and, SO FUN IT'S FREAKY. I recommend this game. Four stars.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is one of the most fun sandbox games. It allows you to build ships and stations, create logical operations, make scripts in game, and anything else you can come up with. Another great thing about this game is you can construct things with precision without have to having to place thousands of cubic meters of wool to create it (*cough* Minecraft *cough*). It gets weekly updates, has Steam workshop mods, worlds, and ship blueprints support, and you don't have to port forward just to host you're own online game. The only cons I can see with this game is community griefers, but that's an issue with any sandbox game and there aren't that many now (At least what I've played). So why not get it!?

Early Access Review

Unoptimized garbage.

That's Space Engineers in two words.  I'm on a pretty new rig with a decent graphics card, a fresh Windows install with up-to-date drivers, and this game barely even wants to start up properly, never mind actually play.  The fact that the devs behind this godawful nightmare 1) started development on a new game (Medieval Engineers) before this one could even run properly; and 2) were totally on board with the paid mods fiasco that Valve tried to make standard, is a firm display of ethical integrity on par with the worst mainstream game publishers such as EA.

If this game is ever fixed, it'll totally be worth a purchase.  But that will probably never happen.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had this game for quite a while now and have been impressed with the steady development.  Updates are frequent and follow a content-bug fix-polish cycle.  New content seems to be prioritised based on what is most missing from the game after listening to player feedback.  The developers clearly have their own vision of the game they are making, but they listen to the audience they have attracted when deciding how best to go about integrating the many necessary elements.

Early Access games have something of a bad reputation, but the team behind Space Engineers have behaved with integrity thus far and I definitely feel I have gotten my money's worth of fun already.

The game is still clearly not a finished, bug-free, polished product.  However, barring financial considerations, I have no reason to doubt that it will be in time.

I want that to happen, so I recommend this game so more people may buy it and the makers are less likely to run out of money and more likely to get a decent reward for behaving admirably.

What is the game like itself?  Sort of advanced giant virtual lego in space I suppose.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In space engineers, you take control of a Space engineer in the middle of an asteroid belt with no way to leave, despite having multiple spacecraft around him to pilot. The goal in the engineer's mind is unknown, but it likely has to do with attempting to create the Enterprise, or Star Destroyer. The engineer has two ways to accomplish this. He can either manually mine ores and resources using his drill and spacecraft, or he can use his powers of mind control to conjure up entire ships out of nothing. When he tries to mine things using drills, his drill has an invariably long lifetime, meanwhile he must charge himself every five minutes or so, or he risks dying of being tired. As he constructs his ship, he uses parts built by an assembler, which uses robots to assemble various refined ores into complex parts. He then uses various parts to construct spacecraft while welding in an inconsistent manner, which may explain why his ships usually fall apart when shaked. When he uses his magic, however, he can remain awake forever without negative consequences.

However, despite all the magic said engineer can use, he cannot stop a small meteor from blowing up his spacecraft. The meteor storm is the least of his worries, however. He must be on constant lookout to not knock his ship about before he has installed all necessary systems, or he risks it falling endlessly into the void. He must also be careful not to cut his ship in half, since engineers cannot understand the concept of welding two halves of a ship together without special merge blocks". You can however

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: While I do recommend this game you should be aware of the following problems:

The game developer (Keen Software House) leaves much to be desired, interaction with the community is in general very poor and they have a habbit of implementing features that are poorly thought out and often untested, normally this would be okay but for some reason they do not have a development branch so player are often forced to deal with game breaking bugs, some of which can take weeks to be resolved, still they do update every Thursday which is a plus even if it's just bug fixes.

Performace in the game is very bad, even with a fairly high end machine you can expect problems, planets for example can consume 6GB of memory on low textures, at higher texture settings it's possible to reach 10GB or more which is insane, multiplayer is poorly optimized with frequent crashes on the dedicated server, this is extra annoying since you die if you get disconnected while not inside a cryo chamber, you also need a DirectX 11 card, I'd suggest the GTX 970 at the minimum, performance is significantly better in space.

If you like this type of game and have a good PC you may be able to overlook the bugs, it's a lot of fun when everything works and there is a nice variety of mods on the Steam workshop, I'm hopeful these issues will be fixed in the near future but for now you should carefully consider before buying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Planets: the most hyped and anticipated feature ever, and they totally botched it. My computer has 16 gigs of RAM, and on loading the world I get low memory warnings from Windows. On two occasions it totally crashed my system, a monster rig with 8 cores at 4.0 ghz, 16 gigs of RAM, and a GeForce 980. This is a system that can run any modern game maxed out with no problems, and this killed it.

Furthermore, planets only work with DirectX 11, which is still buggy and has horrible lighting problems. They still have not fixed Windows 10 support, either. DirectX 9 mode does not work on Windows 10, and results in a stuck process that you cannot kill without restarting the entire system.

How is Keen responding to these problems? By IP banning anyone who complains from their forums, without even so much as a  warning. This is their way of silencing dissent.

Everything this developer has ever promised has fallen short; Miner Wars 2081 and Miner Wars Arena were abandoned, and now they've totally failed at the most-anticipated feature in Space Engineers. Don't buy this game if you expect to be impressed or treated right as a customer. This developer is a notorious scammer: they take your money and give you empty promises, then never finish any game they make or properly implement promised features. They have not had a single game reach full release; they all remain early access" until it stops selling due to people being fed up with the lack of progress and they abandon it."

Early Access Review

Space Engineers may still be an Early Access title, but this game is definately worth it and I strongly recommend this game to those who enjoy sanbox/survival type games. The game does a great job at making you feel small. Flying around space and mining off asteroids gives you a good perspective to how big the universe really is. This game does support the Steam workshop and mods are frequently being uploaded to the workshop to provide the game with new or improved content to suit your playstyle or needs. With that being said, I feel it'd be best to start with the negatives...

As I've mentioned before, this game is still in early access and is expected to have bugs and crashed here and there. From what i've experienced so far, here are some things you should take note of:

- Don't try to load a world with more that 15 mods enabled, your game will most likely freeze or crash to desktop. (However, this may just be my system)

- This game does require a beefy PC when it comes to running planets. I was only able to get a max framerate of 40 on a planet without foilage and on the lowest possible graphical settings. For those who do have a decent system shouldn't have any issues however.

- Whilst playing on a relatives server, i've noticed anything that a client does, would also appear for the server host. E.g - I take my helmet off, it'll come up with the same message for the host. Or if I had ran out of materials for an upgrade, it'll not only tell myself, but it would also tell the host.

- When connecting to lets say, a friends server with mods enabled, sometimes the mod will not install correctly and will not work. I'm having this issue currently on a relatives server and are still trying to solve it.

- Changing your graphics setting from lowest to highest or vice versa can cause your game to crash.

- The camera is a bit dodgy at times, especially when it comes to crouching or mining in small spaces.

(There are many more that I could go into detail about, but those are the most obvious)

Seeing there will be problems with any game that's in early access, don't feel it should stop you from buying it. The game is updated every now and again and the devs are trying their hardest to fix the problems. That being said, this game will keep you occupied for hours and in my opinion, is definately worth a try.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was a revolutionary concept back in 2014, and even now it is a pioneering project in the game industry, with full voxel based sandbox system in space with high detail graphics, planets, asterodis, mining, industry building, mechanic systems etc.
Unfortunately it became too big for the developers to finish as a quality game, and the underlying multiplayer concept is not working, it is too late to move to a professional netcode like raknet. This implies, that the concept of faction based, persistent, multiplayer game with lots of players (30+) will never be realised, which makes the game a pointless, unfinished sandbox. It can be considered as an abandonware, stuck in early access, with constant pretense as being fixed, while underlying fundamnetal problems never get fixed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like this game. The idea of a spaceship minecraft-like game with an awesome physics engine was really apealling and when I first go it I wasn't dissapointed. But this game has many issues I think you should know about before buying it. When I first bought the game it was fairly buggy but not bad for an alpha title and it's weekly releases left me confident it would only improve from there. I was wrong. The developers were so focused on adding more and more content to the game it quickly became unstable. On planets as far as I can tell maintaining a solid 30 fps is difficult and 60fps is flatout impossible. The game also encounters huge performance issues when you attempt to build larger ships so you can kiss any hopes of massive battleships goodbye. The multiplayer leaves alot to be desired with simulation speeds tanking to .60 or below. But the worst part is, despite all these issues the developers continue to release weekly updates adding more flash to the game with seemingly no intent on fixing it's performance.

Now if you stay inside these limitations it is a very fun game if you enjoy building spaceships and I will still come back and play it every onceand a while. If you can learn to live with framerate issues and bugs you'll probably enjoy it too but in it's current state I just can't recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers or the Minecraft for adults.

I had a lot of fun playing this game (270Hours). As others mentioned the game is the most fun if you have someone to play it with.

Pro:
+ Build what you want. The only limits are your computing power and your imagination.
+ Dedicated servers with whitelists via Steam-groups
+ Realistic physics
+ Voxel-based Engine / Worlds / Ships (everything is destroyable)
+ Active community / developers
+ Weekly (and usefull!) Updates

/ Some minor bugs

Cons:
- Bad netcode at the moment (they had a better one but reverted it some weeks ago cause of bug-fixing)

Space Engineers or the Minecraft for adults.

I had a lot of fun playing this game (270Hours). As others mentioned the game is the most fun if you have someone to play it with.

Pro:
+ Build what you want. The only limits are your computing power and your imagination.
+ Dedicated servers with whitelists via Steam-groups
+ Realistic physics
+ Voxel-based Engine / Worlds / Ships (everything is destroyable)
+ Active community / developers
+ Weekly (and usefull!) Updates

/ Some minor bugs

Cons:
- Bad netcode at the moment (they had a better one but reverted it some weeks ago cause of bug-fixing)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the freshest gaming concepts to come along in years. Take the crafting of Minecraft, the Zero-G insanity of Shattered Horizon and the resource gathering and tech-trees of Starcraft and you've got Space Engineers.

The one element that really captured my attention to begin with, was how after mining, I'd have to float above the conveyor belts, drop the ore from my inventory and then that phsyical item would drop into the refinery and I could both hear and watch (through its own inventory screen) as it refined that ore into a usable format.

You take the stuff out, select what you want to build then place it and the framework appears.. you then pull out your welder and get to work, eventually your object will be fully formed.

Throw in co-op, meteor showers and the incredible ability to build and colour your own moving spacecraft and this is just an endless experience.

Hit me up, I need a co-op partner!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game that has set standards to Early Access game. Every 2-3 weeks you get a brand new update with amazing additions to the game. I have played this since it first appearred on steam, and they have came a long way to the game you know now. Also dont ferget, every update they make, the next day will be a bug fix for any problems from that mistake. The devs work hard and have rising above the rest.

This game is a great spaceship/space station building game with tons of machanics that revolve around the laws of motion. There are dozen function blocks, such as; Pistons, motors, lights, drills, grinders, welders, gravity genarators!!!, and a great conveyor system.

What you build is limited to your imagination. Build from you imagintation, or recreate a starship from yr favorite game or show! Check out the screenshots of what YOU could build in this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is probably my most favorite game at the moment. It allows you to set your imagination free, build any kind of ship you can imagine, and even make them usable. After you make the ship, you can smash into some asteroids and witness some of the most top-notch destruction physics I've ever seen.

Remember, this game is only in alpha, so you're going to see some bugs, and a lot of the things that have been promised for the game hasn't been added in yet.

I honestly think that this game completely lives up to its price tag, and more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its Alpha stages the game is already cool for a few hours, but can get boring rather fast because there is not much to do yet in my opinion. It requires some patience due to its Early Access business model. It has a great deal of potential at being a nemesis to Minecraft for space exploration with better graphics, but will seemingly require a great deal of work to reach that status. You have multiple scenarios at your disposal, but in each, it is basically the same at the moment; you need to find Uranium as fast as you can while at the same time save your given energy in the games various styles of survival beginnings.

There is a multiplayer mode that is not yet in the condition it should be but it is getting there slowly but surely. Things take time, of course. Dedicated servers seem to be a step for the developers in the near future so players can build huge things with their friends...and destroy them.

A decently high computer is required. Mine is sort of lower mid range at the moment and there are some graphical bugs due to that and presently multiplayer seems to me impossible to play. Like I said though, if you are a player who enjoys going out and gathering resource to build a huge space station or some ships to your exact liking with not-so-many-yet building parts yet then this is a game for you. I can't wait until it has AI to fight off however, and a faster way of moving the high amount of resources you mine from asteroids into processing and storage. It has weapons and blocks designed for item transport but it isn't finished yet due to, again, the Early Access model. It's still an Alpha build and for that, is damn good already.

In the end, a game with a great deal of potential. If you enjoy idea of survival in space" then this is for you for sure."
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is quite playable in its early access state, I'm surprised about the quality of this game in its ALPHA stage, if they keep this up, it will be super awesome when it's in release stage.

It has some performance issues but if you don't abuse the world with excessive digging, meteorites, blowing up too much stuff and etc, it will be playable.

They're also updating this game every thursday like clockwork, adding new things and fixing more stuff every time... and sometimes breaking some stuff, but they release hotfixes too.

So, bottom line, I do recommend this game for the creative kind that like realistic space games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fanastic game to kill time with. I spent hours upon hours in Creative mode, just building ships. When mod/Workshop support came into play, it changed building. New weapons, blocks and even little things like a lamp.

And yes, Survival is fun too. Better with a group of friends! In my honest opinion, it is kinda boring when you solo Survival mode.

Now with the Exploration stuff, it's like a fresh way to play. You could get lost and never know what you're going to find.

You could:- Find a new asteroid to make home. Or maybe you get lucky and find a station built already!
- Find a new ship, or even ships that players sent in for Exploration. Claim it, if you want. Scrap it, destroy it.

Just becareful, some are booby trapped... D: Maybe.

Audio:Awesome background music. Very chillax for floating in space~

Sound effects are great too, a few could use some improvements. But not a problem!

Other Stuff:There's many algorithms working, especially on collision or explosions. So if you lag up, it's just stuff computing/calculating. Keep that in mind!

Weekly updates are very welcomed! They're also very quick to fix bugs introduced from that update.

I think that's all I wanted to cover. Hmm. You kinda do need a decent computer to run it, just a heads up there.

-stamps paper- RECOMMENDED!

I cannot recommend this game at its current stage. Unless you build something that doesn't move (no pistons or rotors), or only ever play single player, your creation will break immediately or at some point down the road.

Creative is great fun since every time something breaks you don't need to worry about resources having been lost due to bugs and desynchronizations, you just build a new one. There still isn't a whole lot to DO in the game though, just lots to look at. Planets are a huge step forward though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game that anyone can enjoy. It's less about following objectives as most games are these days and more about using your personal creativity to create your own fun. Like Garry's Mod but in a much cleaners, styled fashion, give users a much more streamlined building system and the tools to do whatever their heart desires. The workshop is rich with mods and other user content, and it's easy to share your creations with others, and just as easy to download and use the creations others make. Weekly updates from the developers means there are constant improvements and fixes coming to the game at a steady pace as well.

However, in my experience when ever I have been on to play the game (Most common times players in the AEST Timezone and similar would be on) The amount of players on servers is limited at best. On rare occasions a 10-15 slot server will be full, but other than that the lack of players can mean a limited interaction with others making playing on servers providing the same experience if not less in terms of player interaction plus issues you might experience with your connection to said server. To resolve this I would highly recommend talking you friend into buying this game or even buying it for them if you wish to play multiplayer, at least until the community grows.

All in all there are probably plenty of games with a bigger player base and more content then Space Engineers, but the ability to sculpt the game to your needs is really unique feature to have in a game and no other game pulls this off better then this. There is plenty of room for new content and improvements but as it is now this is one of the best games on Steam right now and worth every cent. Can't wait for the player base to grow, see you in game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

They've broken a great game.
The game itself is great.  It's fun, you can really push your creativity to meet the challenges of the environment the game puts you in.  However after an update to how character positioning works in multiplayer the multiplayer part of this game has become unplayable for the host.

This game is in Early Access, and I don't rate it down because of the bugs themselves, you expect them in beta releases, that's the point of Beta releases.  Instead I rate this down because how the Beta is run.

First, Friday is a terrible day to release updates.  I'm a developer and there is a reason we release updates on a Tuesday morning. It gives us time to react if something goes wrong.  And when something goes wrong in SE there seems to be no reaction to it. Minor bugs can be fixed for the next release, but if the update breaks the game, retract it, fix it and try again next week.

But my main issue with this Early Access is that it feels like it's been used as an Alpha test. There's a big difference, by the time software goes into Beta release all obvious bugs should have been dealt with.  Beta is to increase the chance of catching obscure bugs and bugs only found by someone using your software in a way you didn't predict. With the positioning update the host's game felt like he was playing in treacle. It was so bad you wonder if the developers even played it before releasing it.

I know I'm on the outside, but I'd ask the developers to review their weekly development process. And please fix the multiplayer.  An average host sim speed of about 0.5-0.6 is not acceptable, it's unplayable.

Early Access Review

This would be an epic game if it wasn't for one problem in particular... The game has terrible performance problems.  It doesn't matter how epicly fast you think your computer is, how fast you can run your favourite fps shooter etc - You'll be lucky to pull 20fps in this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is a sandbox game which should have gotten better as it slowly emerged from Alpha. However sand continues to leak out the corners and cracks. Game content needed to make the game world compelling is still not really there, new blocks and planets aren't a replacement for AI to fight, or NPCs to trade with.

This game has so much potential for modding, however the ModAPI remains very incomplete. You can get access to the source code to add things, but Keen Software refuse to assign a programmer to sift through the code people give them that would improve the game/modding. You can ask for things to be added, but months later nothing will have happened.

So Keen won't add the content the game needs, and you can't mod it in yourself.
Game runs slower than it did 18 months ago, and needs better hardware/OS as well.
Players have taken to giving a persona to the game Physics bugs, Clang the god of random explosions or crashing into things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello everybody, my name is Shaun Meyers (Kyo Akiara) and I'm the writer of a game review and article website known as Universal Gaming Reviews. My latest Early Access Previews article is completed! This time I'm previewing the upcoming sandbox construction game Space Engineers. While I've never been a big fan of construction based games (mainly because I'm utterly terrible at thinking up things to make) the game is looking pretty promising and if you're a fan of minecraft but have wanted a more sci-fi based game that lets you construct space stations and space ships of small or large sizes then this is the game for you. Thanks for reading folks, happy gaming!

You can read our full preview for the game here: http://www.universalgamingreviews.com/2013/11/early-access-previews-space-engineers/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Terribly optimized and by terrible, I mean 5 -10 FPS. Maybe something's wrong with my rig or so, but I seem to be able to run every other game in my library just fine. Some problems I've ran into: crashes every now and then, corrupted save files, complete lag when standing on planets. Multiplayer makes it lag even more.
There are ways to tweak the game yourself based on your rig, but they're quite a pain to figure out eventually ranging to editing your game files, trying to find the right version of your graphics driver, etc. Don't get me wrong, once I got this game working for a while it was actually really fun, but at the moment, unless you're a diehard alpha tester, I would recommend staying out of this game until this game gets an optimization update.
I still have faith for this game in the future though, the concept is really neat, it's just the terrible current optimizations that bothers me.
I wasted most of my hours in this game trying to tweak it myself.

TL;DR You literally need a NASA computer to run this thing without any sort of bugs/crashes

EDIT: Some typos and other things I wanted to mention

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Two yea and still nothing but customization-intolerant gamepad support? Two years and I'm still stuck rap-tap-tapping on my keyboard to flutter my thrusters while listening to people yap and sing and squawk about how wonderful Xpadder is?

No, don't tell me about Xpadder. No, I won't use it. If I was going to I'd just use the Saitek profiler anyway. No, I'm not going to. I do not WANT to emulate zero-or-full keypresses with an analog device, that's why I quit playing Freelancer.

And that's why I'm uninstalling this.

I'm sick of waiting for proper device support. I'm sick of waiting for basic, first year functions that no other 6DOF game would have ever been forgiven for lacking.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Review as of January 27, 2016)

I will preface with this:
This is most certainly an early access peer review. Space Engineers updates weekly, sometimes even more frequently, and constantly changes, adjusts, and updates factors that may alter gameplay.

I'm an aspiring aerospace engineer. I've set my sights on attending the ever prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where some say aerospace engineering was founded. Naturally, I immediately devoted some attention to Space Engineers for this reason. Using voxels, modules, and some ingenuity, you can create incredible entities. One may pay homage to great movie and show starships, or develop real-life historic vehicles largely responsible for mankind's presence in space..... or you can do whatever you want, create whatever you want, and play however you want.

Let's get down to brass tacks and discuss what currently works and what could use improvement:

What works:An innovative ship and space station creation system with robust options in function and form through voxels and parts.
Some realistic grounding with physics, especially with inertia and momentum.
Two varied game modes (enduring survival and imaginative creative) with adjustable environments and settings.
A mod-friendly execution.
What could use improvement:Multiplayer. Long time veterans knew this would be first on the list. Network optimization is poor and gameplay frustrating.
Performance in general. This is a pressing issue to Keen Software House's Marek Rosa and should likely be addressed within the year. Let's hope!
Static animations most certainly testament to the game's early access nature. (Most evident with astronaut movement.)
Painting. Painting is the stuff of nightmares. Be prepared to fight the poor paint-application system.
What doesn't work:Building two separate station / habitats and connecting them together with voxels. (Some things are just too difficult to cut-and-paste.) This is an exercise in patience.
Ultimately, Space Engineers is a fascinating game. If you have any desire to design, create, and fly your own spacecraft, then this is a wonderful experience. Share your creations with your friends, enjoy the vast network of mods available to you, and start your own space empire!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very fun and interesting game to play with friends or just by yourself. I would recommend starting things easy before tackling the major parts of the game like survival mode and sceanrios that pit you by yourself or just limited resources.

The mods are quite interesting, the mod community for this game is creative with their mods and hopefully that will contiue to last.

There are a only couple issues with this game but the primary concern is  the 'tutorial' there isn't any, just a 'guide' of sorts in order for the player to help them guide their way through that particular scenario. Trouble is what supplies go with which? what buttons do i have to press? It's these kind of things that makes tutorials in games like this worth it.

Should you get it? yes you should but prepare to really lose track of time as this game will take a long time for you to make any big progress, this isn't a fast pacing space epic, or some action adventure game. This game is in a field of it's own

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never understood why people like Minecraft. To be honest, it's the graphics. I can get into retro graphics in 2D indie games, but Minecraft just turned me off.

Space Engineers, on the other hand, is gorgeous, and demonstrated to me exactly how much fun a creativity sandbox can be. It receives regular updates with cool new features and is quite stable, and the mod community is very active and supported by the developers.

I've seen a lot of complaints about the developers recently. Most of the ♥♥♥♥♥ing you see about it is undeserved butthurt from people who want their butts kissed by developers; they do an amazing job at supporting existing players/designs/mods compared to most other game communities.

Build spaceships erryday.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Already fun!

In creative mode it gets boring quite fast as there is not that many components yet, but it does allow you to tweaka and test designs so you know what to build.

In survival, building a large ship requires a lot of ore, so it will take some time to get it going.
Which is great as you can create the framework and then work together in multplayer to fill it in.
Inventory management is a bit of a pain, but hopefully the process will be improved in future patches.
The refinery supplies directly to the assembler, but currently that is the only autmated process.
It would be very helpfull if one or more storage container could be used to handle the input and output.

Also moving the ore from your drills to the storage on a platform or large ship would be very helpfull.
A collector hooked to a container and a jettison option on the drill could solve the problem in a realistic way.

It could also allow for slightly more efficient mining with all the small blobs or ores floating around during mining.
Creating a mobile gravity platform with collectors on it would automatically scoop up everything and place it into connected storage (or just require a little bit of sweeping or kicking the ore around to get it all in there).

It's early access so I expected a few problems, but so far only storage management and the slow auto-save are the only two. The rest is solid and fun.

I am looking forward to what the future brings for space engineers!
