Early Access Review

This game has gattling guns, I believe you are already convinced that this is a great game. No?

Space engineers is an incredibly well made game, right now it's in development but it is already worth the money. The physics engine is fantastic and it is so enjoyable seeing the ship you just spent hours on making, crash into another ship.
And with the addition of multiplayer and working ship weapons, you can build ships and have dogfights with your friends.

Space Engineers is an absolute joy to play and I cannot recomend it more. I would take the time to make a longer and more detailed review, but I got ships to build, and friends' ships to destroy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to survival games, Space Engineers is very well done. I've spent more time than I like to admit on this game due to the fact that it allows for a challenging, but rewarding experience. As a space engineer, you are unable to perform too many tasks on your own, as your inventory is severely limited and welding/grinding/mining speeds are too slow for massive builds. While that may sound as a bad thing, it is quite the opposite! It forces you to build ships/contraptions to perform the tasks for you, which is an aspect of the game that I really enjoy. If you think you're mining too slow, build a bigger/more efficient ship! If it's taking hours to weld your base, create a ship that can hold more building components and weld faster.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space engineers is in early alpha so it can be frustrating at times.
It has limitless possibilities: tanks, ring worlds, Deathstars. You name it you can build it here.
And Keen updates it WEEKLY with new content and bug fixes.
However I would recommend this to players with only higher end machines at least for now.
The game still has a long way to go as far as optimization.
But personally I think the game is fantastic and has great potential.
If you want to get into a alpha game, build your favorite ship from your favorite sci-fi series and just except the bugs and help shape the game in the forums this game is for you.
If you cant stand sub 40 FPS, CTD every third launch and a somewhat lack of content, stay away for about a year or two…

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extremely fun space game!

As far as I know it's the only game based in space with real physics, this is an excellent game and can be ran on medium spec computers without any issues. Considering this is an early access game it has a very little amount of bugs and it's rare they'll happen. The game feels like it's influenced somewhat from Minecraft however it's still got a good level of detail.
The game is extremely fun and realistic but not too realistic on survival but creative is great for learning what everything does.
It's kinda a spacey sandbox game, you can build whatever you want out of blocks and ship parts and fly your ship around to do whatever you want however it'd be nice if you could do more in this game ( I understand that it's early access and this game is updated all the time.)
It's definitely worth buying this game at this state and it's more than worth the money, if only my friends could run it with their terrible computers I'd be playing it more.
This game is great for killing time and if I could get friends to play it'd be even more fun for longer, this game has real potential it just needs time.

10/10 This game is awesome the way it combines realistic physics with building blocks is fun in a way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to survival games, Space Engineers is very well done. I've spent more time than I like to admit on this game due to the fact that it allows for a challenging, but rewarding experience. As a space engineer, you are unable to perform too many tasks on your own, as your inventory is severely limited and welding/grinding/mining speeds are too slow for massive builds. While that may sound as a bad thing, it is quite the opposite! It forces you to build ships/contraptions to perform the tasks for you, which is an aspect of the game that I really enjoy. If you think you're mining too slow, build a bigger/more efficient ship! If it's taking hours to weld your base, create a ship that can hold more building components and weld faster.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good game, especially when you watch your contraption/ship explode for some reason. Then you do it again for fun. Then you build a big ship and crash it into everything. Then you build a giant space station for no reason but other to look cool. Then you play survival and die instantly because you forgot to refill your energy even though Glados is yelling at you to refill it.

Don't mention the multiplayer aspect, it's pretty much all I said times 10. And awesome dogfights and other fun gamemodes that you can make up yourself! Like, robot wars, capture the flag, etc etc. Anything you can think of you could probably do in this game.

TL;DR Buy it. You don't need to be a rocket scientist to be a space engineer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While we keep in mind that it is very much still an Alpha game, Space Engineers is a quite detailed and sophisticated game, and to a point very challenging.

If you think you can just put down a landing gear, a few blocks, and generator and a engine and call that a spacecraft, you are wrong. Without counter thrusters, gyroscopes and either too much or too little mass, you wont be able to do much with your ship.

I like this game. Def got my upvote.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I highly recommend the game for those who are fans of the study of cosmology and other astronomical subjects. This game is a excellent game where you can build any type of space ship you want. Great game to play together to survive the meteor showers and for building up your own economical base.
The game has good graphics, doesn`t glitch, and has frequent updating. In updates they add very good items such as sensors and newer cockpits and other building materials. I find the idea amazing of producing artificial gravity in a environment containing microgravity, the idea is great. They made the physics of this game realistic (such as the moment of Inertia, and that there is no friction in space). In the loading screen there is something to read (quotes from Astronomers like Galileo Galilei, Isaac Newton, and many others) instead of just having a screen with a picture and a sign saying: Loading...

MAIN COMMENT: Good game, good physics, good ideas, great building materials (being expanded every month), and plenty of settings to create a environment which you would want. Highly recommend for astronomy/physics/space fans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me first say that regardless of my small playtime in this game, I've still been keeping tabs on the development and workings of it.

Quite honestly, this game is the model by which all other early access indie games should abide by.

Most early access games will put out a game and do a billion bug fixes in their update and/or attempt to release some new content that just leads to loads more bugs to fix, and they all rely on the excuse Oh
date: but it's early access." These guys are not the same. Although things do have their bugs (as does all code)
recommended: the developers of this game always tend to pump out new things that add another nice element to the game in addition to fixing the bugs that may have existed from older builds.\n\nWhat's even better about it is that bugs are far less common in this game than in other early access games! It's great to see quality work in such a small span of time (every 7 days or so). This shows me that there are still some indie devs out there that don't take complete advantage of the "Well
hoursPlayed: it's an alpha" excuse
voteText: which is such a rarity amongst the top indie game devs (no offense to them
helpfulPercent: I'm only speaking my honest opinion). Due to this
votesHelpful: I can confidently say that even though this game is amongst the top selling steam games
votesTotal: I truly think it deserves more attention and credit that it already has. Why? I've just explained it all to you
votesFunny:
but allow me to list it:

1.) Consistent weekly updates
2.) Clean work-even though their updates are weekly

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space engineers is... The perfect combination of Minecraft Creativity combined with fun with physics we find in games like Garry's mod. Although many early access games have been an amazing waste of time and money, this game offers the player an original and addicting experience. Creative is a lot of fun, but from the survival gamemode I still expect great things (Although not being at all boring). All of you who have not bough this game yet; BUY! BUY! BUUUUUUUY!

Edited: 25-6-2015
The survival has more than developped into a well run machine. The addition of mods make the experience a lot more fun as well. Besides the fun with physics we are getting more and more options to operate the ship systems. Sensors allow you to automate systems within an area for example. Ingame scripts can be run through Programable blocks.

All and all, this game is worth much more than they ask for it. But they won't, because they aren't EA. SPACE ENGINEERS IS LOVE, SPACE ENGINEERS IS LIVE!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is the epiphany of what Legos in Space would be, you can create from the most simple ship with barely anything but your imagination, to a Hulking behemoth-class capital ship that could rival with the deathstar itself, the potential offered in this game is gigantic, and its very well playable despite being on alpha stage (at the moment of this review).

The creative mode allows you to create at your hearth's content without worries of materials or energy usage, and the survival mode requires critical thinking by the number of materials you can get, energy consumption, meteor showers and the size of your ship based on your ability to micromanage each and every resource, and to have at least some degree of anticipation for a backup plan in case something goes wrong.

Lastly, the online space battles while are limited for now in resources and needs optimization, do not dissapoint, specially on the collision models, just looking at the capital ships with major damages and still battling is enough to keep you entertained for lasting hours.

edit: oh and you can mod the game on steam workshop, which i ve found easy to use!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have heard people comparing this game to Minecraft, saying that it is a Minecraft in space."

In reality
date: it is much more.\nThis game requires more thinking and problem solving skills than Minecraft
recommended: and it doesn't even have hostile enemies (at the time of this review).\nI like this game because it allows me to design ships and other structures to solve a specific problem or to fulfill a specific combat role. I really enjoy perfecting the ideas for my ships
hoursPlayed:
and this game is perfect for that.

My main problem with it is that building is redundant.
However
voteText: this is likely just my tendency to get bored easily. The game actually has ways to make building faster
helpfulPercent: such as symmetry and a function to place a large amount of blocks at once.\n\nIt will take a little while to get used to the controls and game mechanics
votesHelpful: but it isn't really a notable issue
votesTotal: and you can get used to the controls within an hour of playing.\n\nThis game also has the potential for an amazing ship-to-ship combat simulator
votesFunny: if you can get enough people in your game.\n\nYou also need a fairly good computer to play this game smoothly
commentsCount: especially if you plan on building larger structures.\n\nOverall. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to build ships and structures in space
column16: and people who have fun ideas and like to build them.\n\nFeel free to contact me if you want more information as to how I rate this game
column17: or if you have any questions."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space engineers is... The perfect combination of Minecraft Creativity combined with fun with physics we find in games like Garry's mod. Although many early access games have been an amazing waste of time and money, this game offers the player an original and addicting experience. Creative is a lot of fun, but from the survival gamemode I still expect great things (Although not being at all boring). All of you who have not bough this game yet; BUY! BUY! BUUUUUUUY!

Edited: 25-6-2015
The survival has more than developped into a well run machine. The addition of mods make the experience a lot more fun as well. Besides the fun with physics we are getting more and more options to operate the ship systems. Sensors allow you to automate systems within an area for example. Ingame scripts can be run through Programable blocks.

All and all, this game is worth much more than they ask for it. But they won't, because they aren't EA. SPACE ENGINEERS IS LOVE, SPACE ENGINEERS IS LIVE!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While we keep in mind that it is very much still an Alpha game, Space Engineers is a quite detailed and sophisticated game, and to a point very challenging.

If you think you can just put down a landing gear, a few blocks, and generator and a engine and call that a spacecraft, you are wrong. Without counter thrusters, gyroscopes and either too much or too little mass, you wont be able to do much with your ship.

I like this game. Def got my upvote.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIf you like simulation games with a sense of realism and few limits this is the game for you. The physics engin in fantastic, the building system is easy and complicated all at the same time. Mining and looking for resources isn't unbearable. And the energy system with reactors and solar panels offers many options. I love the survival mode but Creative is a great way to stretch your imagination and make something epic or a world to play survival in. The ability to switch game settings and options for saved worlds makes saved games very replayable and customizable. 8.5/10 The only thing missing from this game is some PVP modes not just PVP servers and is missing mobs. Who doesn't like fighting aliens or space worm infested astroids?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is the epiphany of what Legos in Space would be, you can create from the most simple ship with barely anything but your imagination, to a Hulking behemoth-class capital ship that could rival with the deathstar itself, the potential offered in this game is gigantic, and its very well playable despite being on alpha stage (at the moment of this review).

The creative mode allows you to create at your hearth's content without worries of materials or energy usage, and the survival mode requires critical thinking by the number of materials you can get, energy consumption, meteor showers and the size of your ship based on your ability to micromanage each and every resource, and to have at least some degree of anticipation for a backup plan in case something goes wrong.

Lastly, the online space battles while are limited for now in resources and needs optimization, do not dissapoint, specially on the collision models, just looking at the capital ships with major damages and still battling is enough to keep you entertained for lasting hours.

edit: oh and you can mod the game on steam workshop, which i ve found easy to use!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have heard people comparing this game to Minecraft, saying that it is a Minecraft in space."

In reality
date: it is much more.\nThis game requires more thinking and problem solving skills than Minecraft
recommended: and it doesn't even have hostile enemies (at the time of this review).\nI like this game because it allows me to design ships and other structures to solve a specific problem or to fulfill a specific combat role. I really enjoy perfecting the ideas for my ships
hoursPlayed:
and this game is perfect for that.

My main problem with it is that building is redundant.
However
voteText: this is likely just my tendency to get bored easily. The game actually has ways to make building faster
helpfulPercent: such as symmetry and a function to place a large amount of blocks at once.\n\nIt will take a little while to get used to the controls and game mechanics
votesHelpful: but it isn't really a notable issue
votesTotal: and you can get used to the controls within an hour of playing.\n\nThis game also has the potential for an amazing ship-to-ship combat simulator
votesFunny: if you can get enough people in your game.\n\nYou also need a fairly good computer to play this game smoothly
commentsCount: especially if you plan on building larger structures.\n\nOverall. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to build ships and structures in space
column16: and people who have fun ideas and like to build them.\n\nFeel free to contact me if you want more information as to how I rate this game
column17: or if you have any questions."
column18: April 30, 2014

This is like Minecraft evolved, in space. The basics are the same: Mine, refine, build, repeat, but with the complexity cranked up  (Along with the upper limit of creativity) to 11. In other words, the new Adult" Minecraft.

With that said
date: some things are far too clumsy in Early access

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is really fun to play with your friends, and i know i dont have so many hours played on it, but just in the beginning of the game it was pretty fun, it takes some time to figure out the basics like fuel for you ship, how to mine, building and all that stuff. But once you know how to play the game, its fun to survive. And of course you can also ♥♥♥♥ the whole galaxy up with some crazy killer ship you build in creative mode. This game also have some random things sometimes like meteors shooting down places (you can turn those off if you dont like randomly loosing something on your ship/station or dying) Theres also other ships that will just fly in randomly like private sails and commercial satelites (of course you can turn them off) that has sentry guns that will shoot you if you get too close, and lets not forget you get to choose if you want a small, large or extreme amount of asteroids. Multiplayer is also REALLY fun both with friends and random people, survival is hard in the beginning, but becomes fun after you get more experienced while creative is fun from the beginning, but i would recommend watching the tutorial because it has some really usefull stuff. And i havent incountered any bugs yet. I give this game 9/10 because i really enjoyed the time i have played it, but i would love to see some more character animations.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSpace Engineers is a fantastic game, and it excels in offering a somewhat realistic, fun, and creative experience. It's damage engine is unparalleled, creating dents, rips, and holes in the game's wide variety of blocks. In Space Engineers the player can create an infinite variety of space stations, large ships, and small ships. The player can play in creative mode, with infinite materials and electricity, or in survival mode where they must manage resources, electricity, and pprotect themselves from a variety of cargo ships
date:
ranging from unarmed small ships, to massive ships covered in weapons. Space engineers also offers a unique multiplayer mode in which players can work together to create ships and stations, or battle each other.

PROS:
- Very fun
- high replayability
- great physics engine
- AMAZING damage engine
- fun combat
- fun singleplayer
-fun multiplayer
-lots of updates
-Steam workshop compatability
- highly customizeable world generation

CONS:
- some glitches (especially in muliplayer)
- difficult to understand in the beginning if you don't have much experience with this kind of game

Overall rating:
Gameplay: 8/10
Multiplayer: 8/10
Singleplayer: 10/10
Content: 9.5/10
Mechanics: 9.5/10

TOTAL: 45/50

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is really fun to play with your friends, and i know i dont have so many hours played on it, but just in the beginning of the game it was pretty fun, it takes some time to figure out the basics like fuel for you ship, how to mine, building and all that stuff. This game also have some random things sometimes like meteors shooting down places (you can turn those off if you dont like randomly loosing something on your ship/station or dying) Theres also other ships that will just fly in randomly like private sails and commercial satelites (of course you can turn them off) that has sentry guns that will shoot you if you get too close, and lets not forget you get to choose if you want a small, large or extreme amount of asteroids. Multiplayer is also REALLY fun both with friends and random people, survival is hard in the beginning, but becomes fun after you get more experienced while creative is fun from the beginning, but i would recommend watching the tutorial because it has some really usefull stuff. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSpace Engineers is a fantastic game, and it excels in offering a somewhat realistic, fun, and creative experience. In Space Engineers the player can create an infinite variety of space stations, large ships, and small ships. The player can play in creative mode, with infinite materials and electricity, or in survival mode where they must manage resources, electricity, and pprotect themselves from a variety of cargo ships

ranging from unarmed small ships, to massive ships covered in weapons. Space engineers also offers a unique multiplayer mode in which players can work together to create ships and stations, or battle each other.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is easily one of the bext examples of a early-access game done right. Content is regular, fast-paced, community inspired, responsive, well made, well presented, shockingly stable for such a rough and quickly building game, and the core premise is itself excellent. Mod support is already enacted, and the community isn't half bad and is very energetic.

I speak no hyperbole when I say this is easily the best space sim sandbox I have played, and I cannot imagine a contender with even close to the same level of freedom.

If you catch it on sale, it's a must-grab. For $20, anyone with even a passing interest in building-type games will want it, and anyone who has ever wanted to be a space man will love it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING, THIS GAME IS COMPLICATED.

What you have here is a mighty fine space sim here.  Although what you may see at first may be like, Wtf, this is Minecraft, but it is not.  Go jump right in survival mode and try to figure things out, or you could go on Youtube and watch a Let's Play. Either is fine. The gameplay is a little slow at first, but then it goes to be one of the most immersive games you will ever play. The survival constantly gives you things to do and gives you more objectives to do solo or with your friends.  For an example you need to go build a mining ship to get uranium ore for your reactor.  Or then, you need to collect resources to build a refinery so you can convert the uranium or into ingots.
Although if you dont like slower-paced build-it games then go back to CoD.  Like I said, the gameplay is slow at first but you wont even care when you have so many things and oppertunites to take and do.

I highly reccomend this game, but only to some people, because not one game can please everyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is one of those games that does it right for an Early Access title.
Yes, the game may have bugs and yes, you are most likely to experience them.
But unlike other reviews on this game, you cannot forget that you are playing an Early Access game.
I don't get why everyone is giving this game bad reviews because of the bugs, unless they somehow expected a bug free environment from an early access title?

Space Engineers gets updated every week on Thursday, and the developers tend to have sleepless nights to make sure they deliver an update every Thursday.
Recently, planets where added to this game, and man, did they deliver.

It's enjoy-full to see how this game has progressed so far -- We went from building ships and then crashing them in single player, to playing survival with friends (or crashing ships with friends) and now, we get to do it all over again, but on beautiful looking planets!
Not satisfied with that? Then take your ship and go land on an alien planet, and do your best to stay alive against those space spiders"!


MultiplayerMultiplayer was added along the way to this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space exploration is the ongoing discovery and exploration of celestial structures in outer space by means of continuously evolving and growing space technology. While the study of space is carried out mainly by astronomers with telescopes, the physical exploration of space is conducted both by unmanned robotic probes and human spaceflight.

While the observation of objects in space, known as astronomy, predates reliable recorded history, it was the development of large and relatively efficient rockets during the early 20th century that allowed physical space exploration to become a reality. Common rationales for exploring space include advancing scientific research, uniting different nations, ensuring the future survival of humanity and developing military and strategic advantages against other countries.

Space exploration has often been used as a proxy competition for geopolitical rivalries such as the Cold War. The early era of space exploration was driven by a Space Race" between the Soviet Union and the United States

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-------
Edit 2
-------

Infinite World Generation lost my job CPS took my kids cant stop playing help


-------
Edit 1
-------

Not a week after I wrote this review, the Devs did another update and added the option of spawning your own asteroids.For those of you who didn't read this review, I noted my only semi-complaint was the lack of random generation/asteroid fields etc. While not 100% random world generated, it is a massive leap in the right direction.

My rating now goes to 11/10

----------------------
Original Review
----------------------

Great game. If you like sandbox-y classics like Minecraft, you will love Space Engineers. Dev's work hard to update the game as often as every week. The only con really is multiplayer (And this is kind of a big one because the game, like Minecraft, can be boring playing only by yourself.) Theres a bit of a desync issue when playing with others but Ive noticed it improve with each patch.

Worth $20? At first I thought it might be a bit overpriced, but taking time to think, I would spend it again.

Great community of builders and survivalists. Plenty of servers to mess around on and the convienent option to play on 'soft server/LAN' mode (you basically make your world public or friend-visible) rather than having to host your own server. Great if you don't plan on trying to build a big community and just want to mess around with a couple of friends.

A real nice recent addition was Blueprints. Basically, it enables you to save your precious builds and not have to care about your stuff getting blown to hell. Before, you have to make an offline private 'hangar/shipdock' world to build your designs and save them and import them to other worlds. Now you can just make something, save it to blueprints and take them with you to other maps, worlds and servers.

A small irritation, not even what I would consider a Con: The world generation options are a bit limited. I would like to see the ability to have a TRUE randomly generated world like Minecraft where every so many 100 kilometers or so, new asteroid fields spawn. However, currently, when you make a map, you select an option for a small (around 3), medium (6) or large (10+) asteroids centralized in the middle of the map. Everything outside of that is just dead space. Now granted, if you run your own server, you can spawn asteroids at locations all you want. But it would still be nice to have the randomly generated world truely.. well, generate stuff other than empty space. Small asteroid clusters and other intersteller phenemena. I think by doing so it will make the game more fun and give way to more of an exploration feeling. Plus, in Survival mode, you really cant afford to leave the asteroid fields and not have access to raw materials.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

i'm finally ready to endorse Space Engineers as a recommended purchase for my friends. recent mods and updates have really brought the game close to being 100% playable and fun. definitely worth early access price, absolutely worth sale prices.

specifically the Exploration update has made this game immense and thus troll proof, while still allowing for that extra edge of full open PVP and griefing in a sandbox builder. servers with fast movement (FTL jump drives or Stargates) and navigation (GPS/Waypoint mod) also now provide the tools for a rich Faction vs Faction endgame without any need for arbitraty rules of engagement.

basically it's time for you guys to start learning this game so we can build a Faction and start dominating.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-------
Edit 2
-------

Infinite World Generation lost my job CPS took my kids cant stop playing help


-------
Edit 1
-------

Not a week after I wrote this review, the Devs did another update and added the option of spawning your own asteroids.For those of you who didn't read this review, I noted my only semi-complaint was the lack of random generation/asteroid fields etc. While not 100% random world generated, it is a massive leap in the right direction.

My rating now goes to 11/10

----------------------
Original Review
----------------------

Great game. If you like sandbox-y classics like Minecraft, you will love Space Engineers. Dev's work hard to update the game as often as every week. The only con really is multiplayer (And this is kind of a big one because the game, like Minecraft, can be boring playing only by yourself.) Theres a bit of a desync issue when playing with others but Ive noticed it improve with each patch.

Worth $20? At first I thought it might be a bit overpriced, but taking time to think, I would spend it again.

Great community of builders and survivalists. Plenty of servers to mess around on and the convienent option to play on 'soft server/LAN' mode (you basically make your world public or friend-visible) rather than having to host your own server. Great if you don't plan on trying to build a big community and just want to mess around with a couple of friends.

A real nice recent addition was Blueprints. Basically, it enables you to save your precious builds and not have to care about your stuff getting blown to hell. Before, you have to make an offline private 'hangar/shipdock' world to build your designs and save them and import them to other worlds. Now you can just make something, save it to blueprints and take them with you to other maps, worlds and servers.

A small irritation, not even what I would consider a Con: The world generation options are a bit limited. I would like to see the ability to have a TRUE randomly generated world like Minecraft where every so many 100 kilometers or so, new asteroid fields spawn. However, currently, when you make a map, you select an option for a small (around 3), medium (6) or large (10+) asteroids centralized in the middle of the map. Everything outside of that is just dead space. Now granted, if you run your own server, you can spawn asteroids at locations all you want. But it would still be nice to have the randomly generated world truely.. well, generate stuff other than empty space. Small asteroid clusters and other intersteller phenemena. I think by doing so it will make the game more fun and give way to more of an exploration feeling. Plus, in Survival mode, you really cant afford to leave the asteroid fields and not have access to raw materials.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To cut to the chase, no I don't recommend this game. But I recommend it to ONLY people who like over complicated and relentlessly hard/sometimes annoying gameplay style, where physics in this game is very realistic, and all of your stats are based on a strict real life scenario, an engineer.

Story Line/campaign: Does not exist (yet)
Gameplay/replayability/learning curve: 2/10
Game mechanics/GUI: 6/10
AI: 10/10
Graphics/art/models/animation: 9/10
Functionality/performance: 6/10
Content provided: 10/10

Survival: 1.5/5
Creative: 4/5

Now why are these scores looking generous yet I'm not recommending the game? So let's start off with saying what is right with the game.

Planets. 'Nuff said. Planets are huge and blow away 99% of the audience's expectations, INCLUDING mine. Planets are big, Space is big, you can jump your ship across a freaking galaxy, and when you get up to Space, OH... is it rewarding. Resources come at you generously, and you don't have to worry about gravity, and it is so... realistic. Launching a rocket up into space is both hard, and rewarding. The content levels are extreme, and visually + sounds... it's amazing. The full combinations of things you can build/make is great, and the developers of this game are excellent. The detail into imagination of creation is tons better than Minecraft, and you can program your ship to GIVE COMMANDS or MAKE IT AN AI!!!! Though it is lonely... so you should make AI to fend off against other AI.

But...

As much as it pains me to admit, the game Space Engineers will never be enjoyable to play. The game is fun at times, but it has a limit of fun because of how the game is played and made. Now don't get me wrong, planets is extremely perfect and the devs could NOT have made it any better. The expectations are over the top. But what is wrong with the game?

Survival, the controls, and everything about the game via core mechanics and controls is HORRIBLE. You have to keep an ever watch on physics, building blocks take forever to build with limited inventory space, and running back and forth from destination to destination getting this and that component at quantities of 10-100 of EACH component, trying to remember what any object requires, topped with your oxygen AND energy AND jetpack hydrogen ticking down is the most ridiculous thing I have encountered on this entire planet! The game is not even worth playing, when things you build, die and disappear so freaking frequently, that you'll also rage quit once every play through and probably not play the game for another while.

Lag is a big concern. Objects colliding is a big deal, and the attempt at generating thousands of trees is a cumbersome experience. Ship parts gets destroyed and disappear at hilarious times when not supposed to, multiplayer servers take time to respond to commands, and few other bugs/glitches to take away from enjoyment, but slightly. Still immersive in the long run, but the core mechanics of this game is extremely stupid, tacked on with bugs makes you sit there pondering at the game.

...replayability and learning curve is JUST NO. Why would I want to replay my game when the game keeps crashing, my ships keep crashing, I keep dying easily, and blocks are TOO DANG HARD to construct?!?!?! How are you supposed to learn any of this? Because of horrible learning curves, 85-90% of my friends don't wanna play survival, ever.

Finally the GUI. What... the... hell is up with the build command complexity. You start with blocks in your quickslots you probably don't use, figuring out how to equip weapons is all tiresome, stiffly implemented, and hard to figure out. The control panel??? A mess. So many clusterfeck options that your brain goes numb, and the defaults of wheels is so WTFU, that building a vehicle on land takes AGES to figure out and get working correctly.

Going back to core gameplay mechanics, sure the game is supposed to be slow. I get that, but if you have actual flaws to deal with, it is like a clog in your brain. SURE... you can store items into your containers and build welders on your ships and stuff and start weldin' but your welders if they even TOUCH objects at times, they just explode along with your resources and then that butt hurt flows through you like a disease of TROLLING... then you'll probably sit back and ponder at the screen for 5-30 minutes wondering, what am I doing with my life?"

The 300 hours I spent into this game is mostly me building up whatever I want (which is the cool part about the game)
hoursPlayed: and going back into the game to see new updates released every Thursday.\n\nThis is why I do not recommend the game. I'm sorry. I really am... as I like this game
voteText: but I want to like it more...\n\nPS: I know it is in alpha still
helpfulPercent: but the potential in this game still exists... yet the devs ignore gameplay value over "perty graphics" and eye candy."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Block sandbox games are popular but Space Engineers really does do something to enrich the genre. It has a moderate learning curve which quickly ramps up depending on how sophisticated you want to go. Like the name says, this game is about engineering solutions to problems and many of those problems are ones you want to create. Want high explosives? Find and mine the minerals. Want to pirate ships? Find ways to attack them or neutralize them (and beware of booby traps), or set up a sever and invite your mates along to help out (copies of SE required). Want to program in C#? No? Well you don't have to but the option is there if you want to create sophisitcaed control and read out systems. Or you can just go in to creative mode and smash stuff into each other in the fully destructive environment.
Developers regularly (and I mean weekly) release bug fixes and occasionally new content and the modding community is active with some very nice mods out there including things like Star Wars which allow for a multiplayer wing attack.
If you like a sophisitcated sandbox with the capacity to make overly sophisicated machinery that can catastrophically fail, this is for you.
Note, while this game is technically" early access and some catastrphic failures can be bugs it is remarkably robust and very playable."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI can easily say that this game is amazing. You combine the wonder of space with (somewhat) futuristic technology with man and you get this. Floating around in a 3d environment with no gravity is mesmerizing, as well as getting caught in the orbit of your own gravity field. Everything is destructible, and for a sandbox game as detailed as it is..it's surprisingly non linear feeling and particles even fly off things that are destroyed. Actual physical non blocky particles that have their own physics. Just amazing. You start off in a tiny spaceship. Your goal is to find an astroid, mine. Do whatever. Build a base, establish a gravity field in it. Get a constant flow of fuel for your gravity (Uranium I believe) Hijack rouge or abandoned ships that are faraway and often difficult to reach and get control of, as they're turned off and are drifting through space. While this is difficult, it can really pay off in terms of materials, fuel, and having a huge spaceship to either use or add onto and make it into your own kind of spaceship. Their is an uncountable variety of things you can do/build in this game, as well as very fun space combat. Space combat is very expensive and can often destroy what took you nearly an hour to build. Ramming ships into others is often looked down upon (atleast in friendly servers) but it is very fun to send your own ship flying through another and making a big hole. Everything feels free and non linear. I raite this game 9.6 out of 10. You can do amazing things especially if you've got a few hours or more to sink into this game with a friend or two.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space Engineers is an open-world sandbox game where you take on the role of a engineer of stellar proportions. While the wonderful screenshots and description of this game are very convincing; the game runs like utter garbage. The developers have built their own engine for this game, but as others have mentioned as well: The game somehow feels like a Unity game. It is well stated that the game is in fact not based off Unity, but the poor performance optimizations tend to shed some similarity between them.

Because this is early access, this sort of problem at the moment; is fully excusable. If the game goes out of early access, then this will be a big problem for many gamers. As other reviewers (even positive ones have mentioned); the game's potential is great and the concepts that it lays out are very unique from other open-world sandbox titles. But if the developers don't start focusing on major performance optimizations, then I expect this game will fall short for a long crowd. My FPS in the game with a GTX 680 4GB card never goes any higher than 28 FPS, and often dips to 3 FPS with all the graphics on low.

Overall, unless you have a GTX titan with 12 GB of RAM and a Core I7 with 4.0 GHz, you will probably not be able to enjoy this game (the low settings make it look really ugly.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perfect start, now plummeting into a bad crash landing...

The game was great. I really love it. It clicked into everything I've wanted from a sandbox. It's a great time consumer, it's a game I've always wanted to be made. Bought it ages ago for a relatively huge amnount of money, but I didn't regret it.
Until since about half a year things went worse. The once smooth performance went drastically low, the game itself is plagued with bizarre glitches after every update. None of those things seem to be addressed - adding more irrelevant content took all the shiny spotlight.

I don't have the best computer but it used to run satisfyingly good; now it's a 800x600 nightmare in about 30 fps... if I don't build too much. Maybe if there was some sort of a warning that I'll have to buy a 3x times more powerful PC after a certain number of patches I wouldn't be ranting.

And even if I had a real gaming rig, Space Engineers would still be unplayable. Multiplayer is a distant memory; there's no real way of enjoyably playing with someone. Single player is not much better.
Everything just explodes, lags, disconnects and crashes. Rotors and landing gears generate more explosive force than actual warheads in the game. Nothing works like it's supposed to. Mining anything is a suicide either literally or performance-wise. Wheeled vehicles can't go a hundred yards without making tons of collision noises, eventually falling apart and exploding or plummeting into the void under the planet surface. Explosions? Explosions! Mr. Torgue must have approved.

Not to mention that actual content is dusty and lacking (What about ladders? hatches? hinges? treads? everything in the workshop?), and must be expanded through gazillion mods that put a strain on the dying performance - or just don't load.

The devs weekly address those issues through their own vision of needed content: the likes of self-detonating dogs (as if eveyrthing wasn't exploding anyway), different colored new" tool variants no one cares about or "modding support" to things that have been already modded ages ago. What's the point of forcing weekly updates and showing off unneeded things if people want a functionable game ?

Sorry KEEN but unless you start making the actual game playable after all these terrible months
date: I'll have to tell people: don't waste your money on it like I did. And I was a real maniac
recommended: I really loved the thing. I know you're just a bunch of indie devs and you always had my sympathy for making this experience possible. I would still be building tons of stuff for the sake of enjoying it... if this game worked.\n\nStart listening to your players
hoursPlayed: they're the ones funding this ordeal. It's been long enough."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Engineers in space!

--Warning-- This game is still in an Alpha state, having huge glitches and other game breaking bugs. These are being fixed, but can be very annoying. Serious FPS issues even with good computers.

Build massive battleships, build drone warships and amazing workshops to make fighters, warheads, nuclear drones or recon ships. Use comm links to increase your visuals or drone range. This game allows you to make tons of cool bases and starships on asteroids, moons or planets.

Crazy amount of playability, giving you 100s of hours of fun with friends or by yourself, building small or big bases that will house your power, ammo, minerals, building materials and everything you need to succeed in the cold darkness of space or the warm embrace of a planet.

You can build mining ships with huge cargo bays to harvest minerals like iron, platinum, gold, nickle and several more to make different tools, building materials and other neat stuff. You will then need a welding ship to help create large buildings or mass produce fighters or more welders/miners. Oh, and your going to need a building or main ship to refine all that ore, store it and process it into useable materials.

The game is buggy, as it requires large amounts of data and takes a toll on your machine, causing crashes and game loss. The game can also cause FPS issues. It has some serious game breaking glitches on occasion and can be very frustrating. Things like rubberbanding, glitching, random mess ups like your ship not stopping and other things are common, save often and keep backups of all your saves.

Frequent updates and a very active developer makes this game promising, hopefully having some major bug fixes and performance upgrades in the future.

I enjoy playing this with my two friends, having built a massive starship and several fighters, a mining ship, a welder, drones and a large warship with a fighter dock, gatling and missle turrets.

Recently, we have built a massive earth base along with a planetary long range ship with a coil cannon and fighters to bomb pirate bases.

You can explore the massive planets for minerals, ice and fuel. Eventually, after your base is created and fully operational you will expand into space to find more planets and moons to mine and colonize.

Personal Rating: 3/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Epic timewaster game. Minecraft in space with jetpacks, vehicles, guns, turrets and huge ♥♥♥ spacecraft that you can build/drive around. Mine resources from asteroids and build space stations and defences and stuff and go raid other peoples' ships. LOTS of stuff to learn and see and very fun to play. The worlds are huge too, literally space infinite (well almost). Good physics engine and playable netcode even on distant servers, although the game has quite a few bugs in its current state (but that's a given for an early access title).

At first I thought this was some kind of realistic space engineering" simulator
recommended: it's more along the lines of very high tech Minecraft with gadgets. Can be played singleplayer or multiplayer and the worlds can be saved just like in Minecraft so you can continue from where you left off."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Space is a cold, unforgiving place.  This is the world that waits for you in Space Engineers, a voxel-based sandbox game similar to Minecraft but with enough twists to mark its own territory in the genre.

In Space Engineers, you must temper the harsh realities of space with a limited set of tools:  A space suit that lasts only a few minutes before requiring a recharge, a set of construction tools (Welder, Grinder, and Drill), and perhaps a space station or ship to keep you alive with scant Uranium fuel.  To last more than a couple of hours, you must find more fuel, via mining ore, which must be put through a refinery before it can be used.  Without Uranium, you can't make more, so making a mistake will cost you your life - and if your ship runs out of fuel - may cost you your progress.  Beyond basic survival, the stars are the limit.  You have your choice of producing the parts for and constructing small ships, large ships, or space stations.  The latter two cost an incredible amount of resources but are strangely satisfying to slave away welding together 2.5 metre blocks of steel for hours on end.  Time invested mining can be minimized with construction of a mining ship and a base to properly refine your ore.

Though scarcely an Alpha version, Space Engineers is an incredibly fun and rewarding experience, but as such you must be willing to put up with occasional glitches and clunky multiplayer.

Early Access Review

Some people could say this is a spin-off of minecraft, that it's unoriginal, that it's completely boring....... I would slap them upside the head for saying that cuz dis gaem is AWESOME!!
first you're in space
second you can build a ship
third you can blow ♥♥♥♥ up
this game is so ingenuitive and amazing because of all the things you can do. If you're a Star Wars nerd like me, imagine any ship from Star Wars (the millienium falcon, the jedi starfighter, the y-wing, the x-wing) and relize that you can build all of them. If you like Star Trek, relize that you could build a replica of the Enterprise. Or, if you're that guy who wants to know what it's like to live in space, then survival is for you. Now, if you're the guy who doesn't know how to learn the controls by his or herself, then you can go to the very helpful Space Engineers website that has their own tutorial videos.(Trust me, you'll need them)
If you're the guy who likes to build stuff and then blow the ♥♥♥♥ out of it, then this is your game.

All in all, this game is really fun, just don't expect it to be fun every moment you're playing, because it does require time and effort to make something worth while. But don't ever give up on something, because it's totally worth it in the end.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

1/28/14
What is amazing about this game is that it is only in alpha. This alpha phase game currently packs more features that most full games I have. It is truely unique and gives me a lot of hope. The developers are AMAZING and there are already a lot of youtube channels with how to guides on how to play. IT IS NOT YET FULLY FUNCTIONAL, but it is really close. The weapons on small ships and the automatic rifle and drills work. The best part, they just added multiplayer up to 16 people. it's still rough, but holy crap is it awesome. The graphics are really good and the building is really easy once you get into it. The only limit is your imagination. The physics of this game are as real as they can get without you needing to be an expert on space physics to play. There are a lot of things in this game to tickle your fancy. If I cannot convince you, look up Bradphusion on youtube and watch one or two of his videos. this game will keep me busy for years to come. Look out minecraft.

REVIEW UPDATE 3/18/14
It happened. KSH added the survival update. It is still a little raw and the implimetation of survival somehow messed up creative for some of my friends, but this game is getting better and better. I already play this way more than any of my other games. My recommendation is to get this game while it's still only $14.99. The devs have announced that they are going back to weekly updates. This game is just amazing.

REVIEW UPDATE 5/9/14
It's been some time since I've updated this review.
The game is still going in a good direction. I am happy with every update as it nears completion.

Cons: It can still be laggy on multiplayer, but they are optamizing it with every update
The worlds are not yet unlimited, but there is enough to keep you busy for a really long time.
Sadly the public multiplayer does have greifers, but every game has griefers.

REVIEW UPDATE 12/11/2014
Been a while since I have updated this review.
But my recommendation stands. This game has only gotten better since the last review update.
That being said, with almost 300 hours into this game, its flaws have started to show themselves to me.

Pros:

*You can build anything. The only limit is your imagination. 10/10 for freedom

*Amazing mod support. There are mods to turn this game into anything you want. If you just want to build in creative for hours at a time, there are mods to enhance that. Want to have large scale fleet battles with your friends? Mods for weapons and combat blocks are also available. 10/10 for the mod community.

*Amazing community. To many people, the fanbase of a game is enough to make or break a game. I am one of those people. No one should ever be afraid to voice a complaint, suggestion or question on a game forum. But so many communities have immature bullies that would rather make you feel bad for having a individual thought than welcome you and help you. This game has an outstanding community with groups for just about any aspect of the game. I used to be in charge of one of the first groups (MEC Enterprises) before life got in the way. There are groups for combat, piracy, building, survival, and even salvaging. Anyone can fit in in this game, and if you don't find something for you, make a group and post it to the hub. People would love to join you. 10/10 for the community.

*Developers. The dev team is fantastic. I have never seen a better team. They actually listen to the community. We the players have as much of a voice in the creation of this game as they do. If a mod is popular enough, they add it to the vanilla version of the game. They have teamed up with a 3D printing company and when you build a ship, they can make a real life model and send it to you. They update every week. They have quality merchandise on their website and in general, they are just great. 10/10 for Developers. Keep up the great work guys.

*Game Play. The game play is great. For zero gravity, the controls are very easy to grasp. switching from ZeroG to a gravity influenced area is without error. Gun play is pretty bad, but it's not a major part or the game and thus not a high priority. Ship weapons and fighter combat on the other hand are amazing yet challenging. Combat in ZeroG is a whole new beast and it doesn't help the fact that you don't know what you are about to get into a dogfight with because they built it. It's both exciting and a new challenge. Building is amazing. If you thought minecraft had building down to a T, this game will blow you away. There are just so many features to building paired with being able to rotate yourself to get a better angle. One of their updates added a projector block, so you can build a ship in creative and then save it as a blueprint, and then you can transfer it over to a survival world where the projector sets up a hologram for you to follow when building the ship. Gameplay 9.7/10 (They had to lose some points for the gunplay).

Cons:

*AI. This is a frequent issue from the community. There is no danger in this game. In minecraft, you have mobs. The worst you get in this game is drifting ships with guns and meteor showers. The lack of danger is my biggest issue. The only reason I want to play survival is because I want to see if I can survive. For a uncharted asteroid belt in outer space, there are surprisingly few threats to challenge you. The only thing that I felt challenged was my patience. The best you can do right now is try to find a PvP server or set something up with friends. That being said, the devs may be planning something so we will wait and see. There is also a way to script basic AI, so I imagine there is something to be found in the steam workshop for download.

*Limitations. While the world can be set to unlimited, there is no procedural generation. You spawn in an asteroid cluster and the asteroids you see are the only ones around you. You can keep going but you will find nothing. There is nothing to explore. **This being said, there was a blog post from the head of the development team earlier this week saying that they will not only add procedural asteroid generation, but they also plan to add direlect ships and stations for you to explore. They will be using designs from the community for the most part.

*Survival. I have no issue with creative, but for me, survival got boring after about 3-4 hours and I went back to dumping a couple hundred hours into creative.

Overall I do not recommend buying this game solely for survival mode, but I recommend it for creative and the community, and to be a part of the creation of the best voxel game I have ever seen.

TL;DR Buy this game.
